(2)  Supply the fire department with evidence of a City of Monroeville Business License. 
(3)  Supply the fire department with evidence of insurance in the comprehensive amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence. 
(4)  Every required alarm system must have installation plans approved by the fire department. 
a.  Plans and specifications for automatic or manual fire alarm systems indicating the location and number of all sending stations including automatic detection devices and signals with specifications of the type, constructions, and operations of the system shall be submitted for approval prior to installation of equipment or wiring. Plans shall include location of the annunciator panel with appropriate zoning nomenclature. 
(Ord. of 4-21-98, Art. II, § 6) 
Sec. 2.5-28. - Adequate instructions; copies of regulations. 
(a)  Every alarm business selling, leasing or furnishing to any use of an alarm system which is installed on the premises located in the area subject to this article shall furnish the alarm user with instructions that provide information to allow the user to operate the alarm system properly, and to obtain proper service with the alarm system at any time. 
(b)  The fire department shall have copies of this article available for review at Fire Station No. 1, 235 East Claiborne Street, upon request. 
(Ord. of 4-21-98, Art. II, § 7) 
Sec. 2.5-29. - Required equipment/information. 
(a)  Any newly acquired fire alarm system or any existing fire alarm system which requires updating or modification following the date of the passage of this article, shall be required to: 
(1)  Be installed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association standards currently adopted as the fire code of the City of Monroeville. 
(2)  To have an automatic audible alarm system cutoff within fifteen (15) minutes of activation for those systems using an audible alarm. 
(3)  Provide emergency access to the protected facility pursuant to one (1) of the two (2) listed criteria, as follows: 
a.  User must provide to the answering service the names and telephone number of at least three persons who can respond to the premises where the alarm occurred within fifteen (15) minutes of being notified at any time with the keys to the premises and the alarm system: this list of names and telephone numbers shall be kept current at all times. The same information shall be supplied to the fire department upon request. Any user of a system other than a fire department central alarm station must supply the same information to the fire department upon request. 
1.  Failure to respond within fifteen (15) minutes after the Monroeville Fire Department attempts to notify key holder shall be a violation of the article and shall subject the individual responsible to a fine of two hundred fifty ($250.00) dollars upon conviction in the city's municipal court. 
b.  If the alarm company agrees, it must have one (1) of its representatives respond to the premises where the alarm occurred at any time, with the keys to the premises and alarm system. 
1.  Under this alternative it is still ultimately the owner of the alarm systems responsibility to have keys available within fifteen (15) minutes after attempted notification by the Monroeville Fire Department. Failure to do so shall be a violation of the article and shall subject the individual responsible to a fine in the amount of two hundred fifty ($250.00) dollars upon conviction in the city's municipal court. 
(4)  All audible alarm systems shall have a sign or notice posted on or near the audible device with the name and telephone number of the person/or persons responsible for service and maintenance of the system. The notice shall be conspicuously posted and readable from ground level. 
(5)  Any alarm system with a zone display must have a diagram posted near alarm panel describing location of zones. 
(6)  Every newly installed required alarm system shall be approved by the fire official and the installer shall furnish to the fire department a fire alarm system certification as described in the fire code of the City of Monroeville (NFPA 72). 
(Ord. of 4-21-98, Art. II, § 8) 
Sec. 2.5-30. - Response to alarms. 
(a)  Whenever a fire alarm is activated in the city thereby requiring an emergency response to the location by the fire department, the fire department personnel at the scene of the activated fire alarm system shall inspect the area protected by the system and shall determine whether the emergency response was in fact required as indicated by the alarm system or whether the alarm signal was a false alarm pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(b)  If the fire department personnel at the scene of the activated alarm system determines the alarm to have been false, said personnel shall make a written report of the false fire alarm, a notification of which shall be certified mail or hand delivered to the alarm user pursuant to the terms of this article, advising the fire alarm user of the occurrence of a false alarm a date, time and location specified in the notice. 
(c)  The fire official or duly authorized designee shall have the right to inspect any alarm system on the premises to which a response has been made at the time of activation of the fire alarm or he may cause an inspection of such system to be made at any reasonable time thereafter, by appointment, with the owner of the property. The fire official shall notify the fire alarm user and any alarm company involved so a representative may be present at the time of inspection. 
(Ord. of 4-21-98, Art. II, § 9) 
Sec. 2.5-31. - Notification of alarms. 
(a)  Alarm signals initiated by manual fire alarm boxes, automatic fire detectors, water flow from the automatic sprinkler system, actuation of other extinguishing, fire or medical emergency alerting systems shall be treated as emergency fire alarms for the purposes of this article. 
(b)  Any monitored, proprietary or central, fire alarm system shall: 
(1)  Within ninety (90) seconds retransmit such an alarm signal to the city's central dispatch through approved non-E-911 telephone lines so the proper emergency equipment may be dispatched. 
(2)  Notify the fire alarm user, by a method listed in subsection (a) of this section, in the quickest possible manner. 
(c)  Trouble signals: 
(1)  Monitored alarms: 
a.  Monitoring companies shall immediately dispatch personnel to investigate trouble signal and notify the owner of the alarm of the status of the situation. 
b.  The equipment owner shall contact an alarm service or maintenance company and have the trouble with the alarm system cleared within seventy-two (72) hours. 
(2)  Unmonitored fire alarms: 
a.  Owner shall immediately investigate cause of the trouble signal, and shall have an alarm system maintenance company repair the system, as soon as possible, but in no event shall the repair of the system take longer than seventy-two (72) hours. 
(3)  Trouble signals shall not be treated as a fire alarm requiring emergency response by the fire department, pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(Ord. of 4-21-98, Art. II, § 10) 
Sec. 2.5-32. - Grace period-New installations. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any new installation or modification of alarm systems for the first thirty (30) days following completion of the installation or system modification. Users installing a new system or making substantial modifications to an existing system shall be entitled to a grace period during which false fire alarms generated by such system shall be deemed non-false alarms. This grace period shall cease thirty (30) days after installation or modification of an alarm system. 
(Ord. of 4-21-98, Art. II, § 11) 
Chapter 3 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Nov. 17, 1987, repealed former Ch. 3, §§ 3-1-3-9, 3-20-3-24, and enacted in lieu thereof a new Ch. 3 pertaining to the same subject matter and herein set out. Formerly, Ch. 3 was derived from an ordinance adopted Mar. 25, 1913, §§ 1-5; Ord. No. 10, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 27, 1958; and Ord. No. 65, §§ 1-5, enacted Jan. 1, 1965. 
Cross reference- Removal of dead animals, § 10-10; limitation on pets in mobile home parks, § 13-28; wild animals protected in public parks, § 14.5-24; domestic animals restricted in public parks, § 14.5-28. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, used in this chapter shall have the following meaning ascribed to them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal control officer: The person employed and designated by the city as the enforcement officer of this chapter. 
    Animal shelter: The premises designated by action of the city for the purpose of impounding and caring for all animals found at large in violation of this chapter. 
    City license tag: A colored metallic tag for dogs and cats, stamped with a number and the year which issued, evidencing current rabies inoculation. 
    Fowl: All fowl, domesticated and wild, male and female, singular and plural. 
    Owner: Any person having property right in any animal, or who keeps or harbors same, or has in his care, or who acts as custodian of same, or who permits same to remain on or about the premises owned, occupied or controlled by such person. 
    Vicious or dangerous animal: Any animal that has, without provocation, or will, without provocation, bite or fiercely attack any person or other animal, or any dog that is of a breed which is bred as a fighting or attack dog, or such dog that has been especially trained as an attack, guard or fighting dog. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-2. - Bird sanctuary-City designated. 
    The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the City of Monroeville, Alabama, be and the same hereby is designated as a BIRD SANCTUARY. 
(Ord. of 11-17-87; Ord. of 12-17-91, § 1) 
Sec. 3-3. - Same-Injuring, etc., of birds; robbing nests; abatement of nuisance; penalty for violation of section. 
    It shall be unlawful to trap, shoot, hunt, or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob bird nests or wild fowl nests. Provided, however, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or menace to health or property, then a complaint may be made to the chief of police of Monroeville, Alabama, and after such complaint being made, the chief of police shall forthwith investigate said complaint and if he deems that such birds are a nuisance or menace to health or property, then he may direct and supervise a means for their destruction. The destruction of said birds shall be made only under the direct supervision and control of the chief of police of the city. 
    Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. of 11-17-87; Ord. of 12-17-91) 
Sec. 3-4. - Cruelty; neglect. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, willfully and cruelly, to injure or kill any animal by any mode or means causing it unnecessary fright or pain, and it shall be further unlawful for any person, by neglect or otherwise, to cause or allow any animal to endure pain, suffering or injury. Acts violating this section shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Failure to provide adequate shelter from inclement weather, especially for puppies and kittens. 
(2)  Failure to provide animals food for a period of more than twenty-four (24) hours or water or care for more than eighteen (18) hours. 
(3)  Abandoning any animal on private or public property. 
(4)  Failure on the part of the driver of a motor vehicle to stop or call the police or other agencies for assistance after striking or injuring an animal by the motor vehicle. 
(5)  Leaving exposed any poisonous substance, food, or drink, for any animal or fowl or to aid or abet any person in so doing, except insect or rodent poison when used for control of insects or rodents. 
(6)  To bait, to attack with violence, to provoke, or to harass an animal, domestic or wild, with one (1) or more animals or humans, for the purpose of training such animal for or to cause, or sponsor to promote such animal to engage in, fights, wrestling or similar contests with or among other animals and humans. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-5. - Minimum area of livestock enclosures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enclose cows, horses, mules or goats in an enclosure less than two (2) acres in area. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-6. - Hogs prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep hogs on his premises. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-7. - Vicious animals. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the owner to harbor or keep in the city a vicious animal, unless the same is securely confined, bound or adequately leashed in such a manner as to prevent such animal from biting or attacking a person or other animal. 
(2)  Wherever a vicious animal is permitted to run at large within a walled or fenced enclosure, or other structure, it shall be the duty of the owner of such animal to give public notice or warning that such an animal is at large within such enclosure by conspicuous posting of a written or printed notice at every unlocked entrance to such enclosure. 
(3)  Whenever a vicious animal is not properly or securely confined, the animal control officer or the police department may order confinement of the animal until the owner provides an enclosure which in the opinion of the animal control officer, is adequate. Until such enclosure is provided by the owner, the animal control officer or the police department may order confinement of such animal with such person or organization as the animal control officer shall determine, or may impound said animal in the animal shelter. The cost of feeding and caring for the animal shall be paid by the owner at a rate not exceeding ten dollars ($10.00) per day. If the owner of such animal fails to provide an enclosure which the animal control officer determines to be adequate within thirty (30) days, such animal may be humanely disposed of by the animal control officer. 
(4)  Whenever any person claims that an animal is vicious, he/she shall make a sworn statement before an officer authorized to administer oaths in the city, and in said sworn statement shall set forth reasons for determining the animal to be vicious. Such sworn statement shall be delivered to the animal control officer or the police department. Upon receipt of such sworn statement, the animal control officer or police department shall immediately make an investigation. If, in the opinion of the animal control officer, or the opinion of the chief of police, the animal is vicious, the animal control officer or chief of police shall order such animal confined. If the owner of the animal does not immediately provide a proper enclosure, the animal control officer or police department shall confine such animal with such person or organization as the animal control officer or police department shall determine or said animal may be impounded in the animal control shelter for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days. If the owner of such animal fails to provide an enclosure which the animal control officer or police department determines to be adequate within thirty (30) days, such animal may be humanely disposed of by the animal control officer. 
(5)  A person owns or keeps a vicious animal in the city at his/her own risk. If a vicious animal escapes from its enclosure or injures any person outside of the enclosure, the owner of such animal shall be criminally liable, whether such escape or injury occurred with or without the negligence of the owner, the keeper or any other person. 
(Ord. of 3-3-98; Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-8. - Animal control officer. 
    The city council shall appoint an animal control officer who shall be an employee of the city and who shall be paid such salary as the city council shall prescribe. The expenses of such officer, in the performance of his duties, together with his salary, shall be paid from the general fund of the city, as may be necessary. It shall be the duty of the officer to enforce the provisions of this chapter; to attempt to rid the city of stray, homeless, unclaimed and diseased animals; to coordinate the functions of the humane officer with the work of the county rabies inspector and the Monroe County Health Department; and to perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the city council. 
(Ord. of 3-3-98) 
Sec. 3-9. - Rabies vaccination-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, keep or harbor in the city any dog or cat which has not been inoculated annually for rabies, as required by Section 3-7A-1, etc., Code of Alabama (1975) or as otherwise required by law. 
(Ord. of 3-3-98) 
Sec. 3-10. - Tags for dogs and cats. 
    Each dog over the age of three (3) months, whose owner resides within the city limits, shall wear a substantial durable collar or harness, to which the inoculation tag, provided for in Section 3-7-4 of the Code of Alabama (1975), shall be attached. Also, attached to such collar or harness shall be an identification tag bearing the name of the owner along with the city license tag (effective June 1, 1998). The city license tag may be purchased from the Monroeville City Hall or from a local veterinary clinic by showing proof of a current rabies inoculation certificate. The city license tag is current from January 1 to December 31 of each year. The annual rate of a city license tag is eight dollars ($8.00); six dollars ($6.00) dedicated to the Monroe County Animal Shelter and two dollars ($2.00) for veterinarian administration costs. It shall be unlawful to attach such tags by wire, rope or other inhumane means. No person shall remove the collar, inoculation tag or identification tag from any animal without the consent of the owner. Cats are not required to wear inoculation or license tags, but proof of annual inoculation and license certificates are required, if requested. 
(Ord. of 3-3-98; Ord. No. 2017-12-002, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 3-11. - Changing tags-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow any dog in his or her charge or control to wear a dog inoculation tag, or license tag, issued for a different dog. 
(Ord. of 3-3-98; Ord. No. 2017-12-002, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 3-12. - Penalties for license violation. 
    The failure or refusal of the owner of any dog or cat to comply with the requirements of section 3-10 shall subject the owner to the following fines or shall constitute an offense in violation of this chapter as follows: 
FINES FOR CITY LICENSE VIOLATION 
First violation: Written warning, plus five (5) days to comply. 
Second violation: Fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) if not resolved within five (5) days for each animal, altered or unaltered. 
Third violation: Fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each animal, altered or unaltered. 
Fourth violation: Shall constitute a misdemeanor, and any person violating this provision shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 3-3-98; Ord. No. 2017-12-002, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 3-13. - Keeping animals so as to constitute a nuisance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any domestic or farm animal or fowl, including cats and dogs, within the city in any manner as will be or may become a menace to public health, or in any such manner as to constitute a public nuisance by attracting insects or vermin, by causing obnoxious odors or noises, or by trespassing on and/or causing damage to property of another. Any animal which continuously barks or emits noise, with no apparent reason, or makes loud and raucous noise at such hours or times so as to disturb the peace of others shall be deemed to be a nuisance. 
    For the purpose of this section "bark" shall mean barking, yelping, howling, growling or otherwise making noise, and "continuously" in regard to barking shall mean barking which occurs during the majority of any twenty-minute period. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-14. - Duty to remove overturned or scattered garbage. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or person in charge of any dog or cat, which has been allowed or suffered by such person to run at large, to pick up and remove to a secure, authorized container any garbage or refuse which the animal has caused to be overturned, spilled or scattered upon any residential lot occupied for human habitation, or upon any right-of-way adjacent thereto, upon demand from the owner or occupant thereof or upon demand of any animal control officer. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-15. - Dog tethering and collars. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tether, fasten, chain, tie, restrain or cause a dog to be fastened, chained, tied or restrained to houses, trees, fences, garages or other stationary or highly immobile objects by means of a rope, chain, strap, or other physical restraint, except in circumstances where all of the following requirements are met: 
(a)  The dog must be tethered by a non-choke type collar to a tether at least ten (10) feet in length and which tether is free from entanglement. 
(b)  The dog must have access to food, water and shelter during any period of tethering. 
(2)  The collar or harness fitted to dogs shall be consist of leather or nylon of not more than two (2) inches in width or chain of not more than one-half (1/2) inch in diameter or width and to be of sufficient strength to control the actions of the dog. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-16. - Dog shelter. 
(1)  A shelter must be provided for all dogs. The shelter must be sanitary, of sound construction, and provide adequate protection from cold and heat. The shelter must have at least three (3) sides and a weatherproof roof; have a solid and sanitary floor; be adequately ventilated; provide shelter from wind, rain, sun, and the elements at all times. The shelter must be placed in a dry area free of debris, feces and standing water. Suitable drainage must be provided so that water is not standing in or around the shelter. 
(2)  The shelter must be large enough for the dog to stand, turn around and lay down without touching the sides or top of the shelter. When outdoor temperatures reach freezing levels, heat must be provided within the shelter or the dog(s) moved indoors or to an area that provides heat and proper shelter for cold weather. 
(3)  A home or apartment may be considered a shelter provided that the dog has access to the interior of the home or apartment. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Sec. 3-17. - Dog pens and enclosures. 
    Any dog confined within a fenced yard must have must have an adequate space for exercise based on a dimension of at least one hundred fifty (150) square feet per dog. Provided, further that where dogs are kept or housed on property without a fenced yard, the owner of such dogs or persons having custody of such dogs shall provide an enclosure or pen for such dogs meeting the one hundred (100) square foot per dog dimension. Such enclosure or pen shall be constructed of chain link or similar type materials with all four (4) sides enclosed, and shall be located no closer than twenty-five (25) feet from any property line. The enclosure shall be of sufficient height to prevent the dog from escaping from such enclosure, and shall meet the requirements of the Alabama Animal Rights Protection Act 13A-11-241. 
(Ord. of 2-17-09(1)) 
Secs. 3-18, 3-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AT LARGE 

Sec. 3-20. - Definition. 
    At large shall mean off the premises of the owner or custodian of the animal or fowl, and not under the immediate control of the owner or custodian. 
Sec. 3-21. - Animals and fowl not to be permitted at large. 
    No person owning or having in his custody animals or fowl shall permit same to go at large to the injury or annoyance of others, nor shall such animals or fowl be permitted at large to roam streets or other public ways of the city. Such action is considered to be a nuisance and dangerous to the public health and safety. 
Sec. 3-22. - Property owners may take possession. 
(a)  Any person finding any animal or fowl at large upon his property to his injury or annoyance may hold the animal or fowl in his possession, and as soon as possible notify the owner if known or the police department or appropriate city officials of this custody, giving a description of the animal or fowl and the name of the owner if known. 
(b)  The animal control officer, officers, agents, servants and employees of the city as soon as possible after receiving notice will be dispatched to appear at the premises to take possession of the animal or fowl. 
Sec. 3-23. - Capture of animals. 
    The officers, agents, servants and employees of the city (including, but not limited, to, police officers) shall have and are hereby vested with the following rights, powers, duties and authority for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and for the protection of the health, welfare and safety of the public: 
(1)  To capture and confine as provided in this article any animal found to be at large. 
(2)  To capture, and to put in quarantine for observation for rabies, any animal found in the city which is suspected of having rabies, or exhibits the symptoms of rabies, or is alleged to have bitten any person, and to humanely destroy or have destroyed, in conformity with Alabama Law, any such animal determined to be rabid. 
(3)  To enter upon any property, whether public or private, for the purpose of effecting any capture herein authorized. 
(4)  To use any reasonable means, including the use of a tranquilizer gun, in attempting any capture under authority hereof, without liability to its owner. 
Sec. 3-24. - Return to owner. 
    If the officer has or with reasonable dispatch can obtain the name of the owner of the animal or fowl, he may return it to the residence address. If there is no one at the address, he will leave a notice where the owner may reclaim the animal or fowl. He will then proceed to the nearest animal hospital or shelter which will accept the animal or fowl and leave it. 
Sec. 3-25. - Owner liable for expenses. 
(a)  The owner or custodian of an animal taken into possession under this article shall pay a board bill on a per diem basis in an amount previously agreed to between the city and the owner of the hospital or shelter. The owner of the animal shall be responsible to pay the entire per diem board bill for any day or part of any day during which the animal is in the custody of the hospital or shelter until redeemed by the owner. 
(b)  The owner of any animal seized or impounded under the provisions of this article shall be required to pay the sum that may be due for seizing and impounding of the animal, as determined by the city council. As to any animal that has not been inoculated against rabies, the owner of the animal shall pay the expense of its inoculation against rabies. 
(c)  The owner of any animal seized or impounded under the provisions of this article shall not be entitled to redemption of the animal until all fees, charges and expenses as provided herein are paid or other satisfactory arrangements for payment are made with the city. 
Sec. 3-26. - Disposition of unredeemed animals. 
    Any animal or fowl found at large not redeemed within five (5) days after its capture may be disposed of in such manner as previously agreed upon between the city and owner of the animal hospital or shelter, unless the identity of the owner is known. If the identity of the owner is known, the animal or fowl may not be disposed of until after the city clerk or other officer gives notice thereof in such manner as the clerk or other officer shall deem reasonable, including personal notice thereof to the owner of such animal, if feasible. The owner of the hospital or shelter is made an agent of the city for the purpose of disposal of the animal or fowl, and his actions in this regard is declared to be for a governmental purpose. 
(Ord. of 9-21-04) 
Sec. 3-27. - Reserved. 
Sec. 3-28. - Disposition of large animals. 
    Should any officer or designated person upon call or upon his own initiative pick up a large animal such as a horse, cow or mule or any other animal not acceptable by any animal hospital or shelter, he is authorized to call a trucking firm or company. The firm or company will convey the animal outside the corporate limits to one of the farms which has a working agreement with the city to handle such cases. The disposition of the animal in this case shall be handled in the same manner as provided in this article. 
Sec. 3-29. - City council to make necessary agreements. 
    The city council of the city is authorized to enter into the necessary agreements with animal hospitals, shelters and farms to carry out the terms of this chapter.

Add the following supplemental sections under Article 110, Requirements for 
Electrical Installations: 
Section 110.2.1: Permits and fees. An electrical permit, issued by the building official of the City of Monroeville, shall be required for any work done on the electrical service equipment of an existing building involving connection or reconnection of the meter, except for reconnection of electrical service that has been disconnected for a period of less than twelve (12) months and requiring no repair work before reconnection. The fee for said permit shall be $25.00 and shall be paid prior the issuance of the permit. Said fee shall include the cost of one inspection of the completed work. Re-inspections, if required because the completed work is non-compliant with this code, shall result in an additional charge to the permit holder of $25.00 per inspection. Permit fees for electrical work done during new construction or during the repair, alteration, or enlargement of existing buildings shall be included in the building permit issued for that project. 
Section 110.2.2: Inspection and approval of wiring installations. Upon the completion of any wiring installation of any building for light, heat or power, it shall be the duty of the person doing the same to notify the building official that the work is ready for inspection. If when inspected, the installation is found to be in compliance with this code, the building official shall notify the utility company that the wiring is ready to be used; thereby permitting connection to the system at the pleasure of the owner or his agent. There shall not be any approval issued on any wiring installation not in compliance with this code, nor shall current be turned on to such installations until such approval is issued. An applicant to the utility company for electrical service connection on any building that has been without power for twelve (12) months or longer shall not be connected to the system by the utility company until the electrical service equipment has been inspected and approved for code compliance by the code official of the City of Monroeville. 
(Ord. of 4-19-05(1), § 2; Ord. of 12-1-09, § 1; Ord. of 8-7-12; Ord. of 11-5-13(2); Ord. of 2-17-15; Ord. No. 2016-12-001, § 2, 12-5-16; Ord. No. 2018-12-002, § 2, 12-4-18) 
Sec. 4-5. - Building permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to: 
(1)  Commence the excavation for the construction of any building, accessory structure, other structure or any required on-site improvement or facility; 
(2)  Store building materials; 
(3)  Erect temporary field offices; 
(4)  Commence the moving, alteration, or repair exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in cost (except decorating such as painting, or wallpapering, replacement of appliances and temporary emergency repairs, such as holes in the roof or exterior walls caused by natural causes); or 
(5)  Other repairs, regardless of cost that change the character of any building, accessory structure, other structure, or use until the building official has issued a building permit, except that the permit fee will be waived for repairs resulting from a natural disaster which has been so declared by the building official. 
    Each application for a building permit in a commercial, industrial, and multifamily zone; and each commercial site where the owner/developer undertakes a project that increases the square footage of the building by a cumulative total of fifty (50) percent or more shall include a landscape plan in accordance with the tree protection and landscaping requirements set forth elsewhere in this Code. 
(Ord. of 11-2-04(2); Ord. of 11-5-13(1))

ARTICLE VII. - HOUSE MOVING AND MOVING OF MANUFACTURED HOMES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted May 5, 1998, added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as §§ 4-70-4-73 herein. 

Sec. 4-70. - Permit required. 
(a)  Required; application. It shall be unlawful to move a house into or through the city, or a manufactured home into the city, without first having secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the city clerk. 
(b)  Fees. The fee for a permit under this section to move a house shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each house, or each section of a house brought by separate vehicle, through or into the limits of the city. The fees for a permit under this section to move a manufactured home shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each manufactured home brought by separate vehicle, or each section of manufactured home brought by separate vehicle, into the limits of the city and left there or moved from one (1) place to another within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-5-98) 
Sec. 4-71. - Permit to be obtained prior to moving; building inspector to ensure compliance with building codes and zoning ordinance. 
    Any house or manufactured home that is moved into the limits of the city and left there shall not be brought into the limits of the city or moved from one (1) place to another within the limits of the city without the permit mentioned in section 4-70 above, and the person moving such house or manufactured home must obtain such permit three (3) days prior to the time the house or mobile is to be moved into the limits of the city, or from one (1) place to another within the limits of the city. In addition, the building inspector or compliance officer of the city shall be required to inspect the house or manufactured home, if the house or manufactured home is to be left within the limits of the city, and no permit to move the house or manufactured home or relocate the same shall be granted unless the building inspector or compliance officer of the city certifies that the house or manufactured home, and the moving thereof, complies with the building codes, zoning ordinances and other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-5-98) 
Sec. 4-72. - Workmanship; safety precautions; notification of police department. 
    Persons licensed under this chapter shall comply with all of the provisions of this article relating to the work being done, must pay the permit fee required for moving buildings, and must keep lights and warnings maintained as may be required and further notify the police department of the city as to the exact time the house or manufactured home will be moved through or into the limits of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-5-98) 
Sec. 4-73. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person failing to first secure a permit before moving a house or manufactured home into or through the limits of the city or who otherwise fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a crime against the city and shall be subject to a penalty upon conviction, as provided in section 1-8. Such persons shall, likewise, be subject to such penalty for any other violation of the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-5-98)

Footnotes: 
--- (9) ---
