(Ord. No. 59, § 1, 12-8-64; Ord. No. 67-A, § 6, 1-11-66; Ord. No. 89, § 3, 1-28-69; Ord. of 9-16-77, § 1; Ord. of 11-20-84; Ord. of 12-7-93; Ord. of 1-21-97; Ord. of 4-4-06; Ord. of 9-16-14; Ord. No. 2018-05-001, 5-15-18) 
Sec. 10-12. - Same-Payment. 
    The mayor, with the approval of the city council, is authorized to negotiate a contract with any person or firm for the billing and collection of the fees and charges, with provisions as to penalties for delinquent payment. 
    All fees or charges not collected otherwise shall be collected by the water works board of Monroeville, acting as the designated agent of the city, and said water works board shall remit the same to the city clerk periodically as they are collected. 
(Ord. No. 59, § 2, 12-8-64; Ord. of 9-16-77, § 2) 
Sec. 10-13. - Covering of transportation vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to transport, haul or carry garbage, rubbish, or refuse through the streets, alleys or public places within the corporate limits or police jurisdiction of the city without having the vehicle or container in which same is to be carried or hauled adequately secured and covered in a manner approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 15, 3-24-59; Ord. of 2-3-09(3)) 
Sec. 10-14. - Dumping at specified place only. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or cause to be dumped, any garbage, rubbish, or other refuse upon any property within the corporate limits or police jurisdiction of the city the other than in a garbage dump as defined in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 14, 3-24-59) 
Sec. 10-15. - Cleanliness of premises-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in possession, charge or control of any premises to keep, cause to be kept, or allow the keeping, on any premises within the corporate limits and police jurisdiction of the city, of garbage, rubbish, refuse, junk, scrap, or trash within which water may accumulate or which may provide a harborage for mosquitoes, rats or snakes, or which may become offensive or deleterious to health or likely cause disease or which offend the general welfare or the aesthetics of the community and thereby cause a substantial diminution in the value of other property nearby; and the same is hereby declared a public nuisance. The duly authorized inspector, as may be designated by the city council, is hereby authorized to inspect any premises in the city or its police jurisdiction for the purpose of seeing that the requirements of this section are being complied with, and it shall be unlawful for any person whomever to resist or interfere with such representative by word, deed or act in the performance of such inspection. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 4, 3-24-59; Ord. of 9-18-12(1)) 
Cross reference- See also, § 11-28 et seq. 
Sec. 10-16. - Same-Maintenance of vacant lots free of debris and weeds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to keep clean and free of all trash, weeds or debris, any vacant lot in the city which is owned by him, or under his control. 
(Ord. of 11-28-50) 
Sec. 10-17. - Littering-Generally; unlawful accumulations; leaving garbage, trash and junk exposed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep, throw or otherwise deposit or cause to be swept thrown or otherwise deposited any garbage, trash, rubbish or other refuse into or on any public street, alley, sidewalk, park or property of another person or property which is in the possession of another person within the corporate limits of the city or permit any garbage, trash, rubbish, or other refuse to accumulate in such a manner that it may be carried and deposited into or on any of the above places by action of the rain, wind or snow; or allow these materials to remain exposed on his premises. 
(1)  Owner's and generator's responsibility. 
(a)  Any person, corporation, establishment, firm, business, owner, agent or occupant of property within the city who generates litter shall be responsible for ensuring such litter is managed, stored and handled in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The owners or occupants or persons in possession of all residential units and commercial establishments shall be responsible for compliance with this article. 
(2)  Areas surrounding commercial establishments and institutions. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each proprietor and each operator of any business, industry or institution to keep the adjacent and surrounding area clear and free of litter, high grass and weeds, as defined under "public nuisance," section 10-1. These areas include but are not restricted to public and private sidewalks, city rights-of-way, roads, alleys grounds, parking lots, loading and unloading areas, and all vacant lots which are owned or leased by the establishment or institution. 
(b)  All construction and demolition contractors, owners or agents shall provide on-site receptacles for loose debris, paper, building materials waste, scrap building materials and other litter products to prevent scattering of such materials by wind or rain if such materials are not otherwise properly disposed of on a daily basis. 
(c)  It is a violation of this article for any private property owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or agent to grant permission to any person to dispose of litter on his property. 
(d)  All commercial establishments shall store their litter in tightly covered containers so as to eliminate wind-driven debris and unsightly litter in and about their establishments. The number and size of containers necessary for each establishment shall be as required to maintain clean, neat, sanitary premises. Spillage and overflow around containers shall immediately be cleaned up as it occurs. 
(3)  Residential property. It shall be the duty of each residential property owner and tenant to keep all exterior private property free of litter, high grass and weeds, as defined under "public nuisance," as defined in section 10-1. These areas shall include, but not be restricted to sidewalks, alleys, driveways, yards, grounds, fences, walls and property lines, public and privately owned storm drains, and vacant lots within the city. 
(4)  Sidewalks and rights-of-way. Each owner, agent, occupant or lessee whose property abuts on city streets shall be responsible for keeping sidewalks and city right-of-way strips between sidewalk and street mowed and free of litter. 
(5)  Sweeping litter into street. It shall be unlawful to sweep or push litter or leaves or grass from sidewalks onto streets where it could be washed into the city storm drains. Such litter and leaves or grass shall be deposited in the proper receptacle which shall be tightly covered or tied to prevent scattering before pickup. 
(6)  Litter generated from improper handling of solid waste. 
(a)  Disposal of garbage by single-family dwellings, duplexes, townhouses and apartments. All household garbage must be stored in tightly closed metal, rubber or plastic cans or in heavy duty plastic garbage bags so as to prevent scattering of garbage by wind, water, traffic or scavenging animals. 
(b)  Disposal of trash in residential areas. 
1.  All trash shall be placed for collection at curbside no sooner than twenty-four (24) hours prior to the designated day for collection. 
2.  Loose trash such as leaves and grass clippings must be containerized in tightly sealed plastic bags or cardboard boxes. 
3.  All trash must be placed at curbside in accordance with current city policy. 
4.  Scrap, lumber, plaster, roofing, concrete, brick and sanding dust, resulting from the construction, repair, remodeling, removal or demolition of any building on private property will not be removed by the solid waste division. All such materials shall be removed by the owner or the contractor responsible for the accumulation of same before, during or after construction. 
5.  It shall be the responsibility of any individual or company doing work on private property to remove from premises residue and rubbish resulting from such work. 
(7)  Cleaning litter or junk from open private property. 
(a)  The compliance officer is hereby authorized and empowered to notify the owner of any open or vacant private property within the city, or the agent of such owner, to properly dispose of litter or junk located on such owner's property. Such notice shall be by certified mail, with return receipt, addressed to the owner at his last known address as the same appears on the records in the Monroe County Court House. The failure, neglect or refusal of any owner so notified to properly dispose of litter or junk with ten (10) days after the mailing of the notice provided for in this section shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(b)  In addition, the city is specifically authorized to institute an action in municipal court to abate any public nuisance created by litter or junk located on any open or vacant property within the city, and the cost of the preceding and the removal of the litter or junk shall be assessed against the owners of such property. 
(c)  Exception. This shall not apply to licensed junk dealers or establishments engaged in the repair, rebuilding, reconditioning or salvaging of equipment, provided that the work area is screened from public view by a fence, hedge, wall or similar device of sufficient height to provide a visual buffer, and is in compliance with the city's junk and zoning ordinances. 
(8)  Litter receptacles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to deposit any item except litter in any receptacle placed for public use as a depository for litter. 
(b)  Any person owning or operating any establishment or public place shall at his own expense be responsible for providing, placing and maintaining litter receptacles adequate to contain the litter generated at the establishment. 
(c)  Litter receptacles purchased and placed in compliance with these regulations shall meet the following minimum standards: 
1.  Construction shall be of such quality as to maintain the receptacle's original shape when placed at an outdoor location, and the receptacle shall be reasonably resistant to rust and corrosion. 
2.  Receptacles shall be constructed and designed or covered in such a manner as to prevent or preclude blowing of litter from the receptacle. 
3.  Receptacles shall be serviced frequently enough to prevent spillage from overflow and to prevent offensive odor. 
(9)  Littering from a vehicle. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drop, deposit, discard or otherwise dispose of litter in or upon any public or private property within the city including but not restricted to, any street, median, right-of-way, sidewalk, park, vacant or occupied lot, body of water, except in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles provided for public use, or in an area designated by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management as a permitted disposal site. 
(b)  The owner of the motor vehicle shall be responsible in the event that any person commits the following unlawful acts while in a motor vehicle, whether it is moving or at rest: It shall be unlawful for any person, while in a motor vehicle, to drop, deposit, discard or otherwise dispose of litter in or upon any public or private property within the city, including but not restricted to, any street, median, right-of-way, sidewalk, park, vacant or occupied lot, body of water, except in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles provided for public use, or in an area designated by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management as permitted disposal site. 
(10)  Escape of load from uncovered vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, hauler, firm or business to haul garbage, paper, trash, sand, gravel, wet cement, construction materials, other loose materials or waste unless the truck or vehicle is covered, secured or sealed to the extent that there will be no loss or spillage during haulage to cause littering of streets and highways or cause a nuisance or hazard to the public health. The deposit of sand or other substance to increase traction, or water or other substance applied on a street or roadway in the cleaning or maintenance of such street or roadway by the government agency having such responsibilities is exempted from the foregoing provisions. 
(b)  Any person operating a vehicle from which any glass, nails or other sharp objects have fallen or escaped which could cause an obstruction or damage a vehicle or otherwise endanger travelers on such public property shall immediately cause the public property to be cleared of such objects and shall pay any costs thereof. 
(11)  Indiscriminate dumping or discarding of litter, junk and solid waste. It shall be unlawful for any person to discard or dump along any street, street median or road, on or off the right-of-way, any household or commercial solid waste or junk on any private or public property unless disposed of in receptacles provided for public use for the deposit of the material, or in an area designated by the state department of environmental management as a permitted disposal site. Any person charged with a violation of this section shall be required to appear in court to answer the charge or charges, and upon the first conviction, shall be fined a minimum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), plus court cost, and on the second, and any subsequent conviction shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus court cost, and shall be subject to any other penalties provided in this article. 
For the purposes of this section, items found in an accumulation of garbage, trash, or other discarded material including, but not limited to, bank statements, utility bills, bank card bills, and other financial documents, clearly bearing the name of a person shall constitute a rebuttable presumption that the person whose name appears thereon knowingly deposited the litter. Advertising, marketing, and campaign materials and campaign literature shall not be sufficient to constitute a rebuttable presumption under this section. No prosecution for violation of this section based on evidence that creates a rebuttable presumption shall be brought against a person unless he or she has been given written notice by a designee of the city that items found in an accumulation of garbage, trash, or other discarded materials contain his or her name, and that, under this section, there is a rebuttable presumption that he or she knowingly deposited the litter. The notice shall advise the person of the penalty for violating this section, and shall provide that, unless the person can present satisfactory information or evidence to rebut the presumption to the designee of the city within fifteen (15) days of the date of the notice, an action under this section may be filed against him or her in municipal court. If the person responds to the notice and presents information or evidence to the designee of the city, the designee shall review the information or evidence presented and make a determination as to whether or not an action should be brought against the person for violating this section. The designee shall provide written notice to the person of the determination, and if the intent is to proceed with an action under this section, the notice shall be sent before an action is filed. 
(12)  Removal of litter from receptacles. 
(a)  The removal of litter from receptacles placed at public parks, fishing areas and other public recreation sites shall be the responsibility of those state and local agencies now performing litter removal services. 
(b)  The removal of litter from receptacles placed on private property which are used by the public shall remain the duty of the owner or operator of such private property. 
(13)  Yard or garage sales and other unauthorized temporary signs. Yard or garage sale and other temporary signs are permissible only on private property on Fridays and Saturdays. They must be removed before Monday morning. Such signs are not permitted at any time on public property such as city street rights-of-way and utility poles. 
(14)  Handbills, etc.-Distribution on streets. It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or cause to be distributed on any of the streets, alleys, parks or any vacant property within the city any handbills, circulars, dodgers or other advertising matter. 
(15)  Same-Placing or throwing in automobiles. It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute in the city any handbill or other similar form advertising material by throwing or placing the same in or on any automobile or other vehicle. 
(16)  Throwing or distributing handbills in public places. No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any public place; provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any public place for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any commercial or noncommercial handbill. 
(17)  Inoperable vehicles, discarded household furnishings, scrap, or junk. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for the owner or owners, or any person in control of or in charge of any residential or commercial property, within the City of Monroeville, to store or keep upon the premises of any residential or commercial property, any inoperable vehicle, discarded household furnishings, scrap, or junk, as defined in section 10-1, unless the same is housed in an approved, enclosed, structure so as not to be viewable from any street, alley, or other public right-of-way, or any private premises, and in such a manner as to present a health, safety, or fire hazard. This paragraph shall not apply to the following: 
(a)  Materials stored or located on the premises of any junk or salvage yard, scrap metal yard, scrap processor, or automobile graveyard; 
(b)  Vehicles being repaired or awaiting repair that are located on the premises of any automobile dealer, automobile repair and body shop or garage, or other vehicle repair enterprise that is duly licensed and operated in compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances of the City of Monroeville, provided said vehicles are so located or stored in a manner as to prevent any health, fire, or safety hazard. 
(Ord. of 4-12-38; Ord. No. 15, § 5, 3-24-59; Ord. No. 59, § 2, 12-8-64; Ord. of 6-8-05; Ord. of 2-18-14) 
Cross reference- Refuse and trash disposal in public parks, § 14.5-22(b); nuisances generally, § 11-20 et seq. 
State Law reference- Nuisances defined, Code of Ala., Tit. 7, § 1081; offense of placing garbage on property of another, Tit. 37, § 426(1). 
Sec. 10-18. - Same-Waterways, drains, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep, throw or otherwise deposit or cause to be swept, thrown or otherwise deposited into or on any canal, stream, public water drain, sewer or receiving basin within the corporate limits or police jurisdiction of the city, any garbage, rubbish or other refuse or to permit same to accumulate in such manner that it may be carried and deposited into any of the above places by action of the rain, wind or snow. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 6, 3-24-59) 
Sec. 10-19. - Violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter, except sections 10-4 and 10-5, shall be guilty of an offense against the city, and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. No garbage, rubbish or other refuse will be removed from the premises of any person failing to comply with the provisions of sections 10-4 and 10-5. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 17, 3-24-59) 
Sec. 10-20. - Garbage bins or containers for businesses-Required; keeping closed. 
    It shall be the duty of every person in possession, charge or control of business premises where garbage or rubbage is created or accumulated, at all times to keep or cause to be kept a garbage bin or container of sufficient size and capacity for the deposit therein of said garbage and rubbage and to deposit or cause to be deposited the same therein, and to keep them tightly closed at all times other than when garbage or rubbage is deposited therein, and to prevent spreading or scattering the same. The garbage bins or containers shall be located behind said business premises or in an area approved by the sanitary department and located at a place conveniently accessible to the collection crews of the said sanitary department; provided, however, the sanitary department may at any time designate the location for the said garbage bins or containers. 
(Ord. of 9-3-85) 
Sec. 10-21. - Same-Pickup at prescribed times. 
    Garbage, rubbage and other refuse will be collected by the sanitary department from the business premise on which it originated at times and intervals prescribed by the sanitary department. 
(Ord. of 9-3-85) 
Sec. 10-22. - Same-Substances prohibited therein. 
    It shall be unlawful to place in any garbage bin or container any acid or dangerous liquids or substances which could cause injury to employees of the sanitary department engaged in removing refuse. 
(Ord. of 9-3-85) 
Sec. 10-23. - Same-Unauthorized removal of refuse therefrom. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any garbage, rubbage, refuse or other like material from any garbage bin or container within the corporate limits or police jurisdiction of the city after it has been placed therein except upon the order of an officer, agent, or employee of the sanitary department or by some other person removing same for disposal. 
(Ord. of 9-3-85) 
Sec. 10-24. - Preparation of cardboard boxes, branches, bushes, leaves and other loose trash. 
(a)  No cardboard boxes will be collected by the sanitary department from residential or business premises unless the same are flattened and placed in the proper location for pick up. 
(b)  All leaves, pine straw, grass clippings, bushes, and other loose yard trash shall be placed in boxes, bags or other containers, other than 55-gallon drums, and placed along any public alley or street right-of-way at a point conveniently accessible to the collection crews; provide, however, the sanitary department may at any time designate the point from which such collection will be made. 
(c)  All trees or parts of trees or bushes to be collected from residential or business premises shall not exceed four (4) inches in diameter and six (6) feet in length. 
(Ord. of 11-5-94; Ord. of 1-21-97) 
Sec. 10-25. - Enforcement procedures. 
(a)  When any police officer or other employee of the city designated by the mayor and city council as an enforcement officer finds any violation of any provision of section 10-17 which he is authorized and required to enforce, such person may issue on forms provided by the city a citation and deliver it to the person in violation, directing the person to appear in the municipal court of the city at a time and on a date stated therein to answer to the charge or charges for the violation, which shall be stated in the citation. 
(b)  If the violation is the first violation of the provisions of article I of this chapter, a violator, in lieu of appearing in the municipal court at the time and on the date stated in the citation, may pay a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), and court cost, within ten (10) days from the date of such citation at the office of the municipal court clerk for the use of the city. The fine for the second and any subsequent conviction shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each conviction, and court costs. 
(c)  The police officers and other employees of the city, designated by the mayor and city council as enforcement officers and authorized to issue citations as provided, are hereby further authorized to swear out warrants or execute affidavits or complaints charging persons with the violations of this Code or article without first having issued a citation for such violation. 
(d)  Any employee of the city designated by the mayor and city council may issue corrective notices to persons, corporations, establishments, companies, owners, tenants, occupants and agents found to be in violation of any of the provisions of this article. The issuance of such correction notice is not necessary for the prosecution of violations of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-8-05) 
Sec. 10-26. - Failure to comply with notice. 
    Any person, corporation, company, firm, business, institution, owner, lessee, agent, tenant or occupant who has been served such notice in accordance with the provision of this article and who shall neglect or shall refuse or shall fail to fully comply with the corrective notices so ordered and/or within the time frame so ordered therein shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-8-05) 
Sec. 10-27. - Penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances, or in the alternative, may be sentenced to pick up litter or any other lawful remedial action which the presiding judge deems to be appropriate. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 6-8-05) 
Secs. 10-28-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECYCLING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Apr. 7, 1992, §§ 1-8, enacted provisions which pertained to recycling. Such provisions have been designated by the editor as Art. II, §§ 10-31-10-38. 

Sec. 10-31. - Purpose and declaration of policy. 
    This article has been created due to the great public interest in preserving the environment by reducing the amount of refuse sent to landfills and incinerators. Because of the solid waste disposal problems and potential solution to some of these problems provided by recycling, it shall be the policy of the City of Monroeville, Alabama, to require recycling of recyclable materials to the fullest extent possible. 
(Ord. of 4-7-92, § 1) 
Sec. 10-32. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Aluminum materials means cans used to hold beverages. 
    Commercial establishment means any nonresidential building or establishment, for profit or nonprofit, including, but not limited to, those used for retail, wholesale, industrial, manufacturing, dining, offices, professional services, automobile service, hotels and motels, restaurants, or shipping and receiving areas. 
    Corrugated cardboard means paper in which a portion has been made to have a wavy surface (alternating ridges and grooves) and is placed between two flat surfaces for the sake of strength and which is commonly use to form cartons. 
    High-grade paper means computer paper, tab cards, white letterhead, ledger, and non-glossy copier paper. 
    Newspaper means newsprint-grade paper, the common, inexpensive machine-finished paper made chiefly from wood pulp, which is printed and distributed. This does not include magazines, slick paper, and telephone books. 
    Nonprofit organization means an establishment, organization or foundation dedicated to public service or culture including, but not limited to, religious, educational, and health care functions. Federal, state and local government establishments are considered nonprofit organizations for purposes of this article. This term shall include civil clubs, youth groups, and extracurricular school organizations. 
    Nonrecyclable material means garbage, debris, and any other materials which are not designated as recyclable materials by the City of Monroeville. 
    Occupier of Land means any residential dwelling, commercial establishment, or nonprofit organization which shall hold title to or shall be in possession of any property in the City of Monroeville, whether as owner, lessee, or tenant. 
    Plastic bottles, jugs and containers means plastic milk jugs and plastic bottles made of P.E.T. (polyethylene terephthalate). 
    Processing facility means a building or enclosed spaces used for the collection and processing of recyclable material. Processing means the preparation of materials in one or more of the following manners: baling, briqueting, compacting, flattening, grinding, crushing, mechanical sorting, shredding, cleaning, and remanufacturing. 
    Recyclable materials means any types of refuse designated by the City of Monroeville within this article to be separate for recycling. 
    Recycling receptacle means a green plastic disposable bag or sack. 
    Residential dwelling means any housing structure with at least one unit, including, but not limited to, single-family homes, mobile homes, and multi-family dwellings. 
    Waste paper products means all uncontaminated paper material such as magazines, slick paper, books, paper, food cartons, cardboard boxes, wrapping paper, bags and discarded letters and envelopes. This does not include newspaper or high-grade paper. 
(Ord. of 4-7-92, § 2) 
Sec. 10-33. - Mandatory separation of recyclable materials. 
    On and after the effective date of this article [May 1, 1992], it shall be mandatory for each occupier of land in the city to separate all designated recycle materials from other refuse in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 4-7-92, § 3) 
Sec. 10-34. - Collection of recyclable materials. 
(a)  The materials designated for recycling in section 10-36 shall be placed in green trash or garbage bags. All recyclable materials may be placed in one (1) bag, or each type of refuse, as designated below, may be placed in separate bags. 
(b)  Recycling bags shall be placed at curbside or other designated spot on the occupier of land's premises for collection on days specified by the city. Collections shall be made by the city, or its agents, on those days. 
(Ord. of 4-7-92, § 4) 
Sec. 10-35. - Scavenging and unauthorized collections. 
(a)  Recyclable materials placed at curbside for collection or in any recycling receptacle placed by the city are property of the city or its authorized collection agent. It is a violation of this article for any person unauthorized by the city to collect or pick up or cause to be collected or picked up any such recyclable materials or receptacles. 
(b)  Nothing in this section is intended to prevent any occupier of land from donating or selling recyclable materials from its own refuse. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, locate, establish, maintain, erect, leave, or otherwise make available any unattended recycling receptacle which is in public view in the city for the purpose of collecting discarded recyclable materials; provided, however, that in the case of undertakings, sponsored by and located on a site owned by a bona fide nonprofit organization, the city shall be authorized to issue temporary permits for the location and use of recycling receptacles. 
(Ord. of 4-7-92, § 5) 
Sec. 10-36. - Recyclable materials. 
    The following types of refuse are designated as recyclable materials by the city. It shall be unlawful for any occupier of land to dispose of recyclable materials in violation of this article. These materials shall be separated from other refuse and placed in recycling receptacles or at collection facilities in the manner described: 
(1)  Aluminum materials: Shall be rinsed and either securely bundled or placed in a recycling bag. Aluminum cans shall be rinsed and crushed prior to placement in receptacles or bags. 
(2)  Corrugated cardboard: Shall be flattened, bundled, tied with cord, and placed in a recycling bag, or in a bundle. 
(3)  High grade paper: Shall be separated from all other types of paper and placed in a recycling bag. 
(4)  Newspaper: Shall be bundled and wrapped with string and placed in a recycling bag. 
(5)  Plastic bottles, jugs and containers: Shall be emptied, rinsed and placed in a recycling bag. All tops, caps, and lids should be removed and placed with nonrecyclable materials. 
(6)  Waste paper products: Shall be bundled separately and secured in bundles and placed in recycling receptacles. 
(Ord. of 4-7-92, § 6) 
Sec. 10-37. - Nonrecyclable materials. 
(a)  All garbage and refuse, not herein designated as recyclable materials, shall be placed in disposable plastic sacks of any color other than green and disposed of as stated in Chapter 10 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Nonrecyclable materials shall not be mixed with recyclable materials. 
(Ord. of 4-7-92, § 7) 
Sec. 10-38. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  The city police department and the public works department are hereby authorized to enforce all provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any occupier of land who violates any provisions of this article, or any regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a monetary fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  Each and every day that a violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 4-7-92, § 8) 
ARTICLE III. - TRASH AND YARD WASTE COLLECTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2019-01-002, adopted Jan. 8, 2019, changed the title of Art. III from "Residential Trash and Yard Waste Collection" to "Trash and Yard Waste Collection." 

Sec. 10-39. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning: 
    Appliance means stoves, refrigerators, freezers, water heaters, air conditioners, and other similar devices, other than those items described in subsection (5) of the definitions of uncollectable trash. 
    Collectable trash means grass clippings, light yard waste, furniture, mattresses, bed springs, small debris, non-putrescible solid waste, metal cans and containers, cloth, paper, cardboard, boxes, and other similar materials, except such items as are defined hereunder as uncollectable trash, production refuse and appliances. 
    Commercial property means any building or property other than a non-multifamily residence or a multifamily residence and shall include businesses, cemeteries, hotels, motels, nursing homes, hospitals, and similar establishments. 
    Garbage means all solid or semisolid refuse subject to decay or putrefaction, all animal or vegetable matter resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of food, and any and all cans, bottles, boxes, paper, or other containers used in the shipping, storage, or preparation of such food or waste. 
    Light yard waste means solid waste, which includes only leaves, grass clippings and shrub and small tree prunings resulting from regular lawn and garden care. 
    Medium to heavy yard waste means solid waste, which includes tree trunk segments, tree limbs or branches exceeding three (3) inches in diameter and eight (8) feet in length. 
    Multifamily residence means a dwelling, which is part of an apartment building, boarding home, or a mobile home park. 
    Non-multifamily residence means an occupied, single-family, or two-family, or townhouse dwelling within the city. 
    Production refuse means items generated or accumulated in the course of a business operation. 
    Trash means non-putrescible solid wastes consisting of light and medium weight yard wastes, furniture, bedding, appliances, paper, cardboard, plastics, wrappings, cans, and similar materials. 
    Uncollectable trash means: 
(1)  Any yard waste exceeding three (3) inches in diameter and eight (8) feet in length. 
(2)  Any item of garbage as herein defined. 
(3)  Any item weighing over five hundred (500) pounds, having a length over eight (8) feet, or being more than (10) inches in diameter. 
(4)  All dirt, gravel, sand, rocks, concrete, bricks, tires, paint containers (unless lids have been removed and paint drained), pesticides, or other hazardous materials. 
(5)  Waste or refuse which is defined, characterized or designated as hazardous by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate state agency by or pursuant to federal law, or which cannot be lawfully disposed of at a sanitary landfill without special treatment or handling. 
(6)  Any refrigerator, freezer, air conditioner and every other type of appliance in which chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs or Freon) were used and the CFCs have not been removed in accordance with EPA regulations and /or no documentation of the removal of the CFCs can be provided. 
(7)  Any production refuses as defined herein. 
(Ord. of 2-3-09(3); Ord. of 11-19-13(2); Ord. No. 2019-01-002, 1-8-19) 
Sec. 10-40. - Trash and yard waste preparation and collection policy. 
    The city will collect yard waste throughout the week. The total amount of yard waste collected per week from each property is limited to two (2) cubic yards, which is equivalent to a pile measuring three (3) feet high by three (3) feet wide by six (6) feet long. Only the yard waste described below will be collected by the city. Medium and heavy yard waste such as tree stumps, logs, root balls, limbs or branches exceeding three (3) inches in diameter and eight (8) feet in length and other tree cuttings or land clearing debris must be disposed of, within two (2) weeks of the time of cutting, by the property owner or the contractor supplying the lawn or tree service to the property owner. 
(a)  Light yard waste. Light yard waste consisting of leaves and grass clippings will be picked up by a vacuuming machine under the following conditions: 
(1)  Leaves and grass clippings must be placed in a furrow near the curb, not a pile. 
(2)  No rocks or other hard objects such as, wood, plastic or metal shall be mixed in with the leaves or grass clippings as these objects may damage the vacuuming machine and result in costly repairs to equipment. 
(3)  Vehicles must not be parked along the curb or in the city right-of-way in areas where leaves and grass clippings are to be picked up. If vehicles are parked in the way, no pick up will occur. 
(4)  Leaves and grass clippings shall not be placed over storm sewer inlets or in drainage ditches so that they prevent proper drainage of storm water. If necessary, wet leaves and grass clippings after placement to prevent them from blowing into the street or drainage ditch. 
Other light yard waste must be piled separately for pick up by a boom truck. 
(b)  Light yard waste. Light yard waste consisting of tree limbs and branches will be picked up with a boom truck under the following conditions: 
(1)  Tree limbs and branches must be cut into lengths no longer than eight (8) feet and their diameter should be no larger than three (3) inches. They must be stacked parallel to the road and separated from leaf and grass furrows. 
(2)  Tree limbs exceeding three (3) inches in diameter and eight (8) feet in length will not be picked up by the city. They must be disposed of by the property owner or the contractor supplying the service. 
(c)  Recycling of light yard waste. The city encourages the recycling of light yard waste into mulch and/or compost. Burying light yard waste in a landfill is not a responsible or cost-effective way to use valuable landfill space. Buried under trash in a landfill, yard waste takes years to decompose and its value is lost forever. Leaving grass clippings on the lawn after mowing to dry and decompose supplies valuable nutrients that improve soil quality. Grass clippings are twenty (20) to thirty (30) percent protein and usually have about four (4) percent nitrogen, two (2) percent potassium and one-half (0.5) percent phosphorus as well as all the necessary trace elements plants need. 
Using oak tree leaves and pine needles as mulch helps the soil to keep moisture, reduce weeds and prevent erosion. 
Compost can be made in your own back yard and may be used for mulch, potting soil or top dressing. Organics including non-greasy food waste, leaves, grass clippings, paper and wood are ideal for composting. 
(d)  Other trash. Other large or heavy solid waste items such as those listed below, shall be picked up by the city for the fees shown in the listing. Pick up must be scheduled and payment made in advance. Arrangements for pick up must be made at the City Hall. Large and heavy item pickups will made on either Thursday or Friday. Once pick up has been scheduled, the items to be picked up must be placed at the curb side by 7:00 a.m. on the morning of the scheduled pick up date. 
Landscape contractors, lawn services and tree service contractors doing work on occupied properties may place leaves, grass clippings, light yard waste near the street on the property from which they were cut for pickup by the city. No yard waste of any type shall be picked up by the city from vacant lots, or from lots with a vacant or abandoned building unless the owner of the lot is paying for garbage collection service on the lot. 
Contractors engaged in the care and maintenance of lawns for commercial or residential properties must keep trash, grass and leaf debris from being left in the streets. Any debris that has been discarded into the streets must be cleaned up. If it is necessary for the city to sweep and/or clean the streets because of contractors discarding the debris into the streets, the city will charge the contractors for the work. 
It shall be unlawful for any pulpwood, commercial tree trimming or tree surgery company or persons engaged in the business of pulp-wooding, tree trimming or tree surgery to place limbs, clippings, cuttings, vegetation or debris resulting from pulp-wooding or tree trimming on any public street right-of-way, as a result of activity on private property, for pickup by city trash vehicles. It shall further be unlawful for any property owner to place limbs, clippings, cuttings, vegetation or debris resulting from activities of one engaged in the business of pulp-wooding, tree trimming or tree surgery on any public street right-of-way for pickup by city trash vehicles.
