(m)  Polling places. 
(n)  Public transportation vehicles, including buses and taxicabs, under the authority of the City of Monroeville, and ticket, boarding, and waiting areas of public transportation facilities, including bus, train, and airport facilities. 
(o)  Restaurants. 
(p)  Restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways, and other common-use areas. 
(q)  Retail stores. 
(r)  Rooms, chambers, places of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings, under the control of an agency, board, commission, committee or council of the City of Monroeville or a political subdivision of the state, to the extent the place is subject to the jurisdiction of the City of Monroeville. 
(s)  Service lines, except outdoor lines that are serviced in a personal vehicle. 
(t)  Shopping malls. 
(u)  Sports arenas, including enclosed places in outdoor arenas. 
(v)  Theaters and other facilities primarily used for exhibiting motion pictures, stage dramas, lectures, musical recitals, or other similar performances. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-94. - Prohibition of smoking in enclosed places of employment. 
(a)  Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed areas of places of employment without exception. This includes, without limitation, common work areas, auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, private offices, elevators, hallways, medical facilities, cafeterias, employee lounges, stairs, restrooms, vehicles, and all other enclosed facilities. 
(b)  This prohibition on smoking shall be communicated to all existing employees by the effective date of this article and to all prospective employees upon their application for employment. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-95. - Prohibition of smoking in private clubs. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all private clubs when being used for a function to which the general fund is invited. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-96. - Prohibition of smoking in enclosed residential facilities. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in the following enclosed residential facilities: 
(a)  All private and semi-private rooms in nursing homes. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-97. - Prohibition of smoking in outdoor public places. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in the following outdoor places: 
(a)  Within a reasonable distance of ten (10) feet outside entrances, operable windows, and ventilation systems of enclosed areas where smoking is prohibited, so as to prevent tobacco smoke from entering those areas. 
(b)  In, and within ten (10) feet of, outdoor seating or serving areas of restaurants and bars. 
(c)  In all outdoor arenas, stadiums, and amphitheaters. Smoking shall also be prohibited in, and within twenty (20) feet of, bleachers and grandstands for use by spectators at sporting and other public events. 
(d)  In all outdoor public transportation stations, platforms, and shelters under the authority of the City of Monroeville. 
(e)  In all outdoor service lines except those serviced by a personal vehicle. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-98. - Where smoking not regulated. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, smoking shall not be prohibited in: 
(a)  Private residences, unless used as a childcare, adult day care, or health care facility. 
(b)  Hotel and motel rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as smoking rooms. All smoking rooms on the same floor must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into areas where smoking is prohibited under provisions of this article. 
(c)  Private clubs, except when being used for a function to which the general public is invited; provided that smoke from such clubs does not infiltrate into area where smoking is prohibited under provisions of this article. This exemption shall not apply to any organization that is established for the purpose of avoiding compliance with this article. 
(d)  Outdoor service lines that are serviced by the use of a personal vehicle. 
(e)  Outdoor places of employment, including construction sites, except those covered by provisions of section 14-95, Prohibition of smoking in private clubs. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-99. - Declaration of establishment or outdoor area as nonsmoking. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of an establishment, facility, or outdoor area may declare that entire establishment, facility, or outdoor area as a nonsmoking place. Smoking shall be prohibited in any place in which a sign conforming to the requirements of section 14-100, Posting of signs and removal of ashtray, subsection (a) is posted. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-100. - Posting of signs and removal of ashtrays. 
    The owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of a public place or place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this article shall: 
(a)  Clearly and conspicuously post "No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol (consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it) in that place. 
(b)  Clearly and conspicuously post at every entrance to that place a sign stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(c)  Clearly and conspicuously post on every vehicle that constitutes a place of employment under this article at least one (1) sign, visible from the exterior of the vehicle, stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(d)  Remove all ashtrays from any area where smoking is prohibited by this article, except for ashtrays displayed for sale and not for use on the premises. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-101. - Nonretaliation; nonwaiver of rights. 
(a)  No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment, customer, or resident of a multiple-unit residential facility because that employee, applicant, customer, or resident exercises any rights afforded by this article or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this article. Notwithstanding section 14-103, Violations and penalties, violation of this subsection shall be a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation. 
(b)  An employee who works in a setting where an employer allows smoking does not waive or otherwise surrender any legal rights the employee may have against the employer or any other party. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-102. - Enforcement. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the compliance officer of the City of Monroeville or an authorized designee. 
(b)  Notice of the provisions of this article shall be given to all applicants for a business license in the City of Monroeville. 
(c)  Any citizen who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with the compliance officer of the City of Monroeville or council of the City of Monroeville. 
(d)  The health department, fire department, or their designees shall, while an establishment is undergoing otherwise mandated inspections, inspect for compliance with this article. 
(e)  An owner, manager, operator, or employee of an area regulated by this article shall direct a person who is smoking in violation of this article to extinguish the product being smoked. If the person does not stop smoking, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall refuse service and shall immediately ask the person to leave the premises. If the person in violation refuses to leave the premises, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall contact a law enforcement agency. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an employee or private citizen may bring legal action to enforce this article. 
(g)  In addition to the remedies provided by the provisions of this section, the compliance officer for the City of Monroeville, department of health official or any person aggrieved by the failure of the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of a public place or a place of employment to comply with the provisions of this article may apply for injunctive relief to enforce those provisions in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-103. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by a fine not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in section 14-101, Nonretaliation; nonwaiver of rights, subsection (a), a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment and who fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first violation. 
(2)  A fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a second violation within one (1) year. 
(3)  A fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each additional violation within one (1) year. 
(c)  In addition to the fines established by this section, violation of this article by a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the suspension or revocation of any permit or license issued to the person for the premises on which the violation occurred. 
(d)  Violation of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, which may be abated by the compliance officer of the City of Monroeville by restraining order, preliminary and permanent injunction, or other means provided for by law, and the City of Monroeville may take action to recover the costs of the nuisance abatement. 
(e)  Each day on which a violation of this article occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-104. - Public education. 
    The City of Monroeville shall engage in a continuing program to explain and clarify the purposes and requirements of this article to citizens affected by it, and to guide owners, operators, and managers in their compliance with it. The program may include publication of a brochure for affected businesses and individuals explaining the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-105. - Governmental agency cooperation. 
    The compliance officer for the City of Monroeville shall annually request other governmental and educational agencies having facilities within the City of Monroeville to establish local operating procedures in cooperation and compliance with this article. This includes urging all federal, state, city, and school district agencies to update their existing smoking control regulations to be consistent with the current health findings regarding secondhand smoke. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-106. - Other applicable laws. 
    This article shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise restricted by other applicable laws. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Sec. 14-107. - Liberal construction. 
    This article shall be liberally construed so as to further its purposes. 
(Ord. of 3-19-13(2)) 
Chapter 14.5 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - PARK AND RECREATION BOARD[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Formerly, Art. I, §§ 14.5-1-14.5-7, pertained to a parks and recreation board and was derived from an ordinance adopted Dec. 14, 1976, §§ 1-8; and an ordinance adopted Sept. 23, 1980. Such provisions were repealed by an ordinance adopted June 21, 1994, §§ 1-9 of which enacted new provisions, pertaining to similar subject matter, designated as § 12-1. Such provisions have been redesignated by the editor as Art. I, §§ 14.5-14.5-7, for purposes of classification. The user's attention is directed to the history note following each section for the specific derivation thereof. Subsequently an ordinance adopted Nov. 2, 2004, repealed § 12-1 and replaced it with a new § 12-1. As this section regarding these provisions already existed in the code as §§ 14.5-1-14.5-7, it has been redesignated as such at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 14.5-1. - Created. 
    That a park and recreation board is hereby created. 
(Ord. of 6-21-94, § 1; Ord. of 11-2-04(3), § 1) 
Sec. 14.5-2. - Membership, appointment, term. 
(a)  Said board shall be appointed anew by each newly elected mayor upon assuming office. Term of office shall run concurrently with that of the appointing mayor. 
(b)  That board shall consist of seven (7) members from the community, one (1) from each council district and one (1) at-large member, appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council, plus the park and recreation coordinator. A board member upon missing three (3) consecutively scheduled meetings shall be terminated to membership of the board and be replaced. 
(Ord. of 6-21-94, §§ 2, 3; Ord. of 11-2-04(3), §§ 2, 3) 
Sec. 14.5-3. - Organization. 
(a)  The board shall be presided over by a chairman selected by the park and recreation board from its membership. 
(b)  All members of the board shall have equal voting power with the exception of the chairman, who shall vote only in the event of a tie. 
(Ord. of 6-21-94, §§ 4, 5; Ord. of 11-2-04(3), §§ 4, 5) 
Sec. 14.5-4. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the board shall be to organize recreation programs throughout the city and its police jurisdiction by further utilizing existing facilities available; to plan for parks and recreation facilities to further meet the needs of the community; and to solicit community involvement in support of recreation activities and facilities. 
(Ord. of 6-21-94, § 6; Ord. of 11-2-04(3), § 6) 
Sec. 14.5-5. - Funding. 
    Funding for parks and recreation programs shall be from the budgets established by the city council and directed by the park and recreation coordinator. 
(Ord. of 6-21-94, § 7; Ord. of 11-2-04(3), § 7) 
Sec. 14.5-6. - Meetings. 
    The chairman shall call meetings of the board at appropriate intervals, but not to exceed three (3) months. Minutes of said meetings shall be presented to the council at regularly scheduled meetings with an activities report. 
(Ord. of 6-21-94, § 8; Ord. of 11-2-04(3), § 8) 
Sec. 14.5-7. - Board to serve in advisory capacity only. 
    The board does not have the power to conduct business on behalf of the City of Monroeville in terms of purchasing, hiring personnel, terminating personnel, authorizing programs, etc. Recommendations from the board should be made to the city council for prior approval. The board should, however, act in the best interest of the city to provide the best recreation programs and advise the city council and the park and recreation coordinator of the ideas in which to accomplish this goal. 
(Ord. of 6-21-94, § 9; Ord. of 11-2-04(3), § 9) 
Secs. 14.5-8-14.5-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONDUCT IN PUBLIC PARKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance of October 6, 1981, not expressly amendatory of the code, has been included herein as Art. II, §§ 14.5-17-14.5-33, at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 3; garbage and refuse, Ch. 10; health and sanitation, Ch. 11. 

Sec. 14.5-17. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the "City of Monroeville Ordinance Regulating Conduct in Public Parks." 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 1) 
Sec. 14.5-18. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    City. The City of Monroeville, Alabama. 
    Director. The director of the parks and recreation department of the city, and the person immediately in charge of any park area and its activities. 
    Park. A park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other area in the city, owned or leased or used by the city or by the public, and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Person. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 2) 
Sec. 14.5-19. - Penalties for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00), or be imprisoned in the city jail for a period not exceeding six (6) months, or be both fined and imprisoned. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 11) 
Sec. 14.5-20. - Park property-Buildings and other property. 
(a)  Disfiguration and removal. No person in a park shall wilfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove, any building, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving or paving material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(b)  Restrooms and washrooms. No person in a park shall fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition. No person over the age of five (5) years shall use the restrooms and washrooms designated for the opposite sex. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 3(1)) 
Sec. 14.5-21. - Same-Trees, shrubbery, lawns, monuments, equipment. 
(a)  Injury and removal. No person in a park shall damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant, or injure the bark, or pick the flowers or seeds, of any tree or plant. Nor shall any person attach any rope, wire, or other contrivance to any tree or plant. A person shall not dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any area. 
(b)  Climbing, etc. No person in a park shall climb, stand or sit upon monuments, vases, fountains, railing, fences or gun carriages, or upon any other property not designated or customarily used for such purposes. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 3(2)) 
Sec. 14.5-22. - Sanitation. 
(a)  Pollution of waters. No person in a park shall throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, pool, or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer, or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will cause, or may result in, the pollution of said waters. 
(b)  Refuse and trash. No person in a park shall have brought in or shall dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage or refuse, or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park, or left anywhere on the grounds thereof, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles, where these are provided; where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 4) 
Sec. 14.5-23. - Loitering; unruly behavior. 
(a)  No person shall loaf or loiter in or upon the public streets, parks, playgrounds, or other public places or public buildings in or contiguous to any park between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day, official city time. 
(b)  No person in a park shall engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusing, insulting or indecent language; or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to a breach of the public peace. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 5) 
Sec. 14.5-24. - Wild animals, birds, ducks, etc.; protected. 
(a)  Hunting, molesting, possessing, exceptions. No person in a park shall hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles at any animal, reptile or bird or duck; nor shall he remove or have in his possession the young of any wild animal, or the eggs, nest, or young of any reptile or bird. Exception to the foregoing is made in that snakes known to be deadly poisonous, such as rattlesnakes, moccasins, coral snakes, or other deadly reptiles, may be killed when dangerous. 
(b)  Feeding noxious substances. No person in a park shall give or offer or attempt to give, to any animal or bird, any tobacco, alcohol or other known noxious substances. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 6) 
Sec. 14.5-25. - Recreational activities-Bathing and swimming. 
(a)  Designated areas. No person in a park shall swim, bathe, or wade in any waters or waterway in or adjacent to any park, except in such waters and at such places as are provided therefor, and in compliance with such regulations as are herein set forth or may be hereafter adopted. Nor shall any person frequent any waters or places customarily designated for the purpose of swimming or bathing, or congregate thereat when such activity is prohibited by the director upon a finding that such use of the water would be dangerous or otherwise inadvisable. 
(b)  Certain hours. No person in a park shall frequent any waters or places designated for the purpose of swimming or bathing, or congregate thereat, except between such hours of the day as shall be designated by the director for such purposes for each individual area. 
(c)  Costume. No person in a park shall allow himself to be so covered with a bathing suit as to indecently expose his person or call forth merited criticism. All bathing costumes shall conform to commonly accepted standards. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 7(1)) 
Sec. 14.5-26. - Same-Boating. 
    No person in a park shall bring into or operate any boat or other watercraft, whether motor-powered or not, upon any waters, except at places designated for boating by the director. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 7(2)) 
Sec. 14.5-27. - Intoxicating beverages. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person in a park shall have brought alcoholic beverages into the park, nor shall any person drink alcoholic beverages at any time in the park. 
(b)  Drunkenness. No person in a park shall have entered, or shall be, under the influence of intoxicating liquor. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 8(1)) 
Sec. 14.5-28. - Domestic animals prohibited; exception. 
    No person in a park shall have been responsible for the entry of a dog or other domestic animal into areas other than those areas designated by the director. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 8(2)) 
Sec. 14.5-29. - Closed areas. 
    No person in a park shall enter into an area posted as "Closed to the Public"; nor shall any person use, or abet the use of any area in violation of posted notices. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 8(3)) 
Sec. 14.5-30. - Permits for certain activities. 
(a)  Required. A permit shall be obtained from the appropriate director or city official before participating in [certain designated] park activities. 
(b)  Inspection. No person in a park shall fail to produce and exhibit any permit from the director, he claims to have, upon request of any authorized person who shall desire to inspect the same for the purpose of enforcing compliance with any ordinance or rule. 
(c)  Interference with permittees. No person in a park shall disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area, or participating in any activity, under the authority of a permit. (Ord. of 10-6-81, §§ 8(4), (5), 9(3)) 
Sec. 14.5-31. - Park operating policy-Hours. 
    Except for unusual and unforeseen emergencies, parks shall be open to the public every day of the year, during designated hours. The opening and closing hours for each individual park shall be posted therein for public information. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 9(1)) 
Sec. 14.5-32. - Same-Closed areas. 
    Any section or part of any park may be declared closed to the public by the director, at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals (daily or otherwise), and either entirely or merely to certain uses, as the director shall find reasonably necessary. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 9(2)) 
Sec. 14.5-33. - Motor vehicles. 
    No person in a park shall leave unattended any motor vehicle in an area not designated for parking; and no motor vehicle shall be left remaining on park property for a period in excess of twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81, § 10) 
Secs. 14.5-34-14.5-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CHILDREN'S PLAYGROUND[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Feb. 15, 1994, §§ 1-7 designated a children's playground and provided for the management thereof. Sec. 1 of the ordinance has been designated as § 14.5-41, and §§ 2-7 have been designated as § 14.5-42 by the editor. It should be noted that the description of the specific parcel of playground property is not set out herein, but is on file in the city clerk's office. 

Secs. 14.5-41. - Designated. 
    Certain real property of the City of Monroeville, Alabama, is designated for use as a children's playground, to be used exclusively and solely for the benefit of the citizens of the City of Monroeville and the public at large as a playground for children of tender age. 
(Ord. of 2-15-94, § 1) 
Sec. 14.5-42. - Management committee. 
(a)  The organization known as the Monroe County Playground Pals is hereby appointed as the committee responsible for the management of design, construction, and maintenance of any improvements at the children's playground. The committee shall exercise, subject to the control of the city council of the City of Monroeville, all the powers of the city with respect to design, construction, and maintenance of the playground facilities and equipment at the children's playground. 
(b)  The Monroe County Playground Pals Committee shall consist of members of this community who serve with no compensation. The Monroe County Playground Pals shall designate those of its membership who shall serve as voting members of the committee. The mayor of the City of Monroeville or his or her designee/representative shall also serve as a voting member of the committee. A majority of said committee at any meeting shall be a quorum, and a vote of the majority of the committee then attending any meeting at which a quorum is present shall be action of the committee. 
(c)  The committee shall have the power to do the acts and things necessary to carry out the objectives and purposes set forth in this article to acquire and receive donations, money or other property for the children's playground, and to do any lawful act necessary or expedient to obtain architectural, engineering, construction and maintenance services and materials for said purposes. In the exercise of this power, the committee shall have no power or authority to bind or obligate the City of Monroeville beyond the amount it receives from private donations and contributions for its purposes. 
(d)  The committee shall have the power to do the acts and things necessary for the continued operation of the children's playground, including but not limited to, establishing reasonable hours for the playground, establishing reasonable rules and guidelines for the use of the playground, and doing any lawful act necessary or expedient for the operation of the playground consistent with this article. 
(e)  The committee shall submit a budget to the city council prior to substantial completion of the project detailing all income and expenditures of the committee. All funds raised by this committee shall be paid into a segregated account, designated "Monroe County Playground Pals", and those funds are to be dispersed solely for the purposes stated herein. 
(f)  The city council of the City of Monroeville reserves the right to amend or repeal this article at any time. 
(Ord. of 2-15-94, §§ 2-7) 
Chapter 14.8 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of Feb. 13, 1979, adopted provisions designated as Ch. 19, §§ 19-1-19-4. In order to maintain the alphabetical sequence of chapters within this Code, said provisions are included herein as Ch. 14.8, §§ 14.8-1-14.8-4. 

Sec. 14.8-1. - Maintenance of right-of-way and tracks. 
    All persons operating railroads in the city, whose tracks cross or are laid in any street, shall keep their tracks in repair and shall maintain and keep in repair and in safe condition for use by the public, free of grass and weeds, free of potholes and protruding spikes and other obstructions, the part of the street between the rails of such tracks and the part lying on either side of such rails for a width of eighteen (18) inches, using for such maintenance and repair materials of an equal or better grade than the material used in surfacing such streets. 
(Ord. of 2-13-79) 
Sec. 14.8-2. - Inspection and repair of tracks, bridges, trestles, etc. 
    The city engineer or other representative shall inspect, from time to time, all tracks, switches, bridges, trestles and other superstructures maintained by persons operating railroads in the city, and if he finds that any such track, switch, bridge, trestle or structure is unsafe, he shall immediately require the person maintaining it to repair it. If, within a reasonable time after such notice, such track, switch, bridge, trestle or structure is not repaired and placed in first-class condition, the city engineer or representative shall swear out a warrant and have the person in charge and control of such railroad system prosecuted. 
(Ord. of 2-13-79) 
Sec. 14.8-3. - Speed of trains in city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any engineer, fireman, conductor, or other employee of any railroad company to operate or cause to be operated, moved or propelled, any train, locomotive or car on any railroad track, whether the same be main line track, side track, spur track, or any other kind of track in the city at a rate of speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(Ord. of 2-13-79) 
Sec. 14.8-4. - Obstructing street crossing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating any railroad, locomotive or car to allow the same to obstruct any street crossing in the city for a longer period of time than ten (10) minutes. 
(Ord. of 2-13-79) 
Chapter 15 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 15-1. - Minimum street width. 
    The city will not accept the dedication of a street by plat, map or otherwise unless the same has a width of forty (40) feet or more. 
(Ord. No. 34, 12-12-61) 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, App. B. 
Sec. 15-2. - Standards for accommodating utilities adopted. 
    The city hereby formally adopts the state "Highway Department Standards for Accommodating Utilities on Highway Rights-of-Way" as standards for use by the city for accommodating utilities on roads and streets under the jurisdiction of the city on those roads and streets which have or will involve the expenditure of state or federal highway funds. 
Sec. 15-3. - Cutting into paved streets. 
    No person shall cut into any paved street for the purpose of connecting to a sewer system, a water system, a gas system or for any other purpose, except in conformance of this Code of Ordinances and when the following conditions are met: 
(a)  A permit must be obtained from the public works department prior to the cutting into any paved street. 
(b)  Any person cutting into a paved street without first obtaining a permit from the public works department shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(c)  Prior to cutting into a paved street in a residential zone, a deposit of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be paid to the city as security for repairs. 
(d)  Prior to cutting into any paved street of three (3) lanes or more, whether same be in a residential zone or otherwise, a deposit of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) is required for security for any repairs. 
(e)  The work done in cutting into any paved street shall be done in a workmanlike manner. No backhoe will be used unless first marked and cut. Repair of the street will include tamping every four (4) inches. Shoulders and curbs of the street shall remain undisturbed. All street repairs shall include proper asphalting in a workmanlike manner. 
(f)  All street repairs from the cutting into paved streets shall be completed within two (2) weeks from the cutting. All repairs of street cuts shall not be considered completed until approved by the public works department of the city. Any repairs to street cuts not completed within two (2) weeks shall be finished by the city. Any expenses incurred by the city in the repair of street cuts may be paid out of the above-mentioned deposit, and any expenses in excess of the above said deposit may be charged to the person responsible for the street cut. 
(Ord. of 9-11-79) 
Editor's note- Ord. of Sept. 11, 1979, enacted provisions designated as § 17-15. At the editor's discretion, in order to facilitate classification and reference, said provisions are included herein as § 15-3. 
Cross reference- Street restoration after utility connections, §§ 17-4, 17-9; utility connection fee when street cut necessary, §§ 17-13, 17-14. 
Chapter 16 - TRAFFIC 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - State traffic laws adopted. 
    In addition to all other provisions of law relating to the speed and operation of vehicles in the city, there is hereby adopted by the city all laws of the state, and all rules and regulations of the state highway department pertaining to the control of traffic and motor vehicles on highways, that are misdemeanors under the state laws, and a violation of such laws, rules or regulations in the city or in the police jurisdiction thereof shall be violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 5-23-78) 
State Law reference- Such laws are contained in Code of Ala., Tit. 36, §§ 1-58(53); this section is authorized under Tit. 37, §§ 585 and 594, and so held in State vs. Springhill, 220 Ala, 125 So. 387. 
Sec. 16-2. - State law definitions. 
    Whenever any words and phrases used herein are not defined herein but are defined in the state laws regulating the operation of vehicles, any such definition thereon shall be deemed to apply to such words and phrases used herein. 
Sec. 16-3. - Compliance with official traffic-control devices. 
    All traffic along the streets within the corporate limits wherein official traffic-control signs, signals and devices are installed shall comply therewith. 
(Ord. of 8-23-38) 
Sec. 16-4. - Turning right at intersection. 
    The driver of a motor vehicle intending to turn right at any intersection in the city shall approach for said right hand turn and said turn shall be made as close as practical to the right hand curb or edge of the roadway, and the driver may proceed after stopping for a red light, stop sign or caution light, when such movement can be made with reasonable safety and giving appropriate signal for such movement of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 114, § 1, 9-10-74) 
Sec. 16-5. - Motor-driven cycles-Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter the term "motor-driven cycle" shall include every motorcycle weighing when fully equipped less than five hundred (500) pounds and every bicycle with motor attached and every motor scooter. 
(Ord. No. 73, § 5, 7-26-66; Ord. No. 73-A, 8-23-66) 
Sec. 16-6. - Same-Adoption of statute. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, within the city or within the police jurisdiction, to commit any act which is declared unlawful by chapter 9 of Title 36 of the Code of Alabama, as amended, which regulates the operation of motor-driven cycles. 
(Ord. No. 73, § 1, 7-26-66) 
Sec. 16-7. - Same-Number of riders. 
    It shall be unlawful for two (2) or more persons to ride upon, or to be carried upon a motor-driven cycle at any one (1) time within the city or within its police jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 73, § 2, 7-26-66) 
Sec. 16-8. - Same-Riding two or more abreast. 
    It shall be unlawful for persons riding motor-driven cycles within the city or within its police jurisdiction to ride two (2) or more abreast. 
(Ord. No. 73, § 3, 7-26-66) 
Sec. 16-9. - Same-Suppression of noise and smoke. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor-driven cycle within the city or within its police jurisdiction unless such motor-driven cycle shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke, and no person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass, a muffler without baffles, or similar device upon any such motor-driven cycle. 
(Ord. No. 73, § 4, 7-26-66) 
Sec. 16-10. - Same-Helmets. 
    Every person operating a motor-driven cycle shall, while so doing, wear upon his head a helmet of the type generally known as a crash helmet, made of hard, durable material and designated for or capable of protection of the head against falls or blows. 
(Ord. No. 73, § 6, 7-26-66) 
Sec. 16-11. - Same-Responsibility for violation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required by sections 16-6 through 16-10; and it shall be unlawful for the parent of any child or the guardian of any ward to authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of such sections. 
(Ord. No. 73, § 7, 7-26-66) 
Sec. 16-12. - Riding bicycle on sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle on the sidewalks of the city. 
(Ord. of 11-26-29, § 1) 
Sec. 16-13. - Driving over fire hose. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating a vehicle to drive over fire hose laid down by the fire department in fighting fires. 
(Ord. of 11-12-30, § 1) 
Sec. 16-14. - Following fire apparatus; driving or stopping near fire. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle other than one on official business, to follow closer than five hundred (500) feet any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or to drive or stop any vehicle within the block where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 1, 8-27-63) 
Sec. 16-15. - Obstructing fire apparatus. 
    It shall also be unlawful for any person in charge or in control of any vehicle, engine or train to recklessly, wantonly, willfully or maliciously delay any fire apparatus of the city, which fire apparatus is going to, or coming from, any supposed or actual fire. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 2, 8-27-63) 
ARTICLE II. - TRUCK TRAFFIC[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance of Mar. 28, 1977 contained "through truck traffic" provisions which, for purposes of uniformity and to facilitate future expansion, the editor has incorporated into existing §§ 16-16 and 16-17. For classification purposes, these sections have been designated as Art. II. See the editor's footnote to Art. III. The user's attention is also directed to §§ 16-20-16-27 for truck speed limits on specific streets. 

Sec. 16-16. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings hereinafter ascribed: 
    Local truck traffic: A truck with a scheduled delivery or pickup point anywhere within the city limits. 
    Through truck traffic. A truck with no scheduled delivery or pickup along any route defined in "local truck traffic," hereinabove. 
    Truck. A tractor-trailer combination, either loaded or unloaded. 
(Ord. of 5-24-77; Ord. of 3-28-78; Ord. of 3-10-79) 
Sec. 16-17. - Routes designated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for through truck traffic: 
(1)  Proceeding east on East Claiborne Street to turn right onto South Alabama Avenue or to turn left on Cherry Street. Said traffic shall proceed east on East Claiborne Street to the State Highway No. 21 Bypass; 
(2)  To travel in any direction along Pike Street between Drewry Road and State Highway No. 21 Bypass. Said traffic shall travel along Drewry Road and State Highway No. 21 Bypass without attempting to circumvent the route by traveling along Pike Street. 
(3)  To travel in any direction along Roberts Drive. 
(b)  This section does not restrict local truck traffic as defined in section 16-16(b). 
(Ord. of 3-10-79; Ord. of 1-8-80; Ord. of 8-5-86) 
Sec. 16-18. - Violation; penalty. 
    Any person violating sections 16-16 or 16-17(a) herein, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00), and not more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. of 5-24-77; Ord. of 2-14-78) 
Sec. 16-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SPEED LIMITS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- This article contains all speed limit provisions enumerated under former Art. II, "Speed Limits," and additional provisions relative to speed limits derived from Ord. of May 23, 1978. The renumbering of this article was necessitated by the use of "Article II," to classify "Truck Traffic." See also the editor's footnote to Art. II. Subsequently, an ordinance adopted Nov. 15, 1988, amended Art. III to read as herein set out. Formerly, Art. III, §§ 16-20-16-25, 16-27, had been derived from Ord. No. 107, § 1, adopted in June 1972; Ord. No. 110, § 2, adopted Jan. 23, 1973; an ordinance adopted May 23, 1978, §§ 1-6, 9; and an ordinance adopted Feb. 17, 1987. 

Sec. 16-20. - Speed limit-Thirty miles per hour. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than thirty (30) miles per hour, by day or night, in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Drewry Road from Camellia Drive, northwest to Alabama Avenue; 
(2)  On Hornady Drive; 
(3)  On South Mount Pleasant Avenue from Pike Street, north to West Claiborne Street; 
(4)  On Dennis Street; 
(5)  On Bergman Street; 
(6)  On Bigger Street; 
(7)  On Mayfield Street; 
(8)  On Pike Street; 
(9)  On Golf Drive. 
    No person shall operate a tractor-trailer, either loaded or unloaded, at a greater speed than ten (10) miles per hour less than thirty (30) miles per hour in the above listed zones of the city. 
(Ord. of 11-15-88) 
Sec. 16-21. - Same-Thirty-five miles per hour. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than thirty-five (35) miles per hour, by day or night, in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway No. 47 (West Claiborne Street) from Golf Drive, east to Academy Boulevard; 
(2)  On Alabama Highway No. 41 (North Mount Pleasant Avenue) from McDonald Street, south to Fountain Drive; 
(3)  On Alabama Highway No. 47 (Pineville Road) from Tallapoosa Street, southwest to Cherry Street; 
(4)  On Alabama Highway No. 41 (South Alabama Avenue) from Poplar Street, north to Drewry Road; 
(5)  On Drewry Road from Camellia Drive, southeast to the city limits; 
(6)  On Whetstone Street; 
(7)  On Lett Street; 
(8)  On South Mount Pleasant Avenue from Pike Street, southwest to the city limits; 
(9)  On Monroe Station Road; 
(10)  On East Claiborne Street from Winston Street to State Highway No. 21 Bypass. 
    No person shall operate a tractor-trailer, either loaded or unloaded, at a greater speed than ten (10) miles per hour less than thirty-five (35) miles per hour in the above listed zones of the city. 
(Ord. of 11-15-88; Ord. of 7-7-15) 
Sec. 16-22. - Same-Forty miles per hour. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than forty (40) miles per hour, by day or night, in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway 21 (By-Pass) from Ivey Street, south to Alabama Highway 21 (Alabama Avenue); 
(2)  On Alabama Highway Nos. 21 and 41 (South Alabama Avenue) from beginning of curb and gutter section near intersection of County Road 37, north to Poplar Street on Alabama Highway No. 41 (South Alabama Avenue). 
    No person shall operate a tractor-trailer, either loaded or unloaded, at a greater speed than ten (10) miles per hour less than forty (40) miles per hour in the above listed zones of the city. 
(Ord. of 11-15-88) 
Sec. 16-23. - Same-Forty-five miles per hour. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than forty-five (45) miles per hour, by day or night, in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway Nos. 21 and 41 from the south city limit, north to beginning of curb and gutter section near intersection of County Road 37; 
(2)  On Alabama Highway No. 47 (West Claiborne Street) from west city limit, easterly to Golf Drive; 
(3)  On Alabama Highway No. 41 (North Mount Pleasant) from a point one (1) mile north of the north city limit, south into the city limit to McDonald Street; 
(4)  On Alabama Highway Nos. 21 and 47 from the northeast city limit, southwest to Tallapoosa Street. 
(5)  On Alabama Highway No. 21 (Monroeville By-Pass) from Ivey Street, north to intersection of Alabama Highway No. 47 (Pineville Road). 
    No person shall operate a tractor-trailer, either loaded or unloaded, at a greater speed than ten (10) miles per hour less than forty-five (45) miles per hour in the above listed zones of the city. 
(Ord. of 11-15-88) 
Sec. 16-24. - Same-Fifty miles per hour. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than fifty (50) miles per hour, by day or night, in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway Nos. 21 and 41 from intersection with U.S. Highway No. 84 north to the south city limit (Alabama Highway No. 12), (approximately 1.2 miles). 
    No person shall operate a tractor-trailer, either loaded or unloaded, at a greater speed than ten (10) miles per hour less than fifty (50) miles per hour in the above listed zones of the city. 
(Ord. of 11-15-88) 
Sec. 16-25. - Same-Other streets and alleys. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than twenty-five (25) miles per hour on any street or alley not specifically mentioned or set out herein. 
(Ord. of 11-15-88) 
Sec. 16-26. - Article provisions to be revised upon extension of city limits. 
    Speed limits as described above shall apply so long as the city limits remain as they are this day (November 15, 1988). In the event they are extended, this article shall be revised to properly cover new territory. 
(Ord. of 11-15-88) 
Sec. 16-27. - Violation; penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or may be imprisoned in the municipal jail, or sentenced to hard labor for the city, for a period not exceeding ten (10) days; for a second such conviction within one (1) year thereafter, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), or may be imprisoned in the municipal jail, or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days; [upon a third] or subsequent conviction within one (1) year after the first conviction, such person shall be punished by a fine or not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or may be imprisoned in the municipal jail, or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding three (3) months, or by both fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 11-15-88) 
Sec. 16-28. - Speed limit-Five (5) miles per hour. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than five (5) miles per hour, by day or night, on any street, alley or parking lot in Veterans Memorial Park, a public municipal park and playground. 
(Ord. of 3-3-98) 
Secs. 16-29-16-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- An Ordinance adopted Nov. 27, 1979, §§ 1-8 enacted new parking provisions, but did not specify manner of inclusion in the Code; hence, codification herein as Art. IV, §§ 16-35-16-72 has been at the discretion of the editors. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-35. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of these regulations, certain numbers, abbreviations, terms, and words used herein shall be used, interpreted and defined as set forth in this section. Unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary, words used in the present tense include the future tense; words used in the plural number include the singular; the word "herein" means "in these regulations;" the word "regulations" means "these regulations." 
    Vehicle: Any device by which any person or property may be transported upon a highway, except those operated upon rails or tracks. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 1) 
Sec. 16-36. - Parking signs required. 
    Whenever, by this article or any other ordinance of the city, any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets, it shall be the duty of the city public work supervisor to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of the alleged offense. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 2) 
Sec. 16-37. - Times regulations. 
    The provisions of this chapter prohibiting the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified or as indicated on official signs except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or official traffic-control device. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 2) 
Sec. 16-38. - Regulations not exclusive. 
    The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 2) 
Sec. 16-39. - Signs or markings for angle parking. 
    The public works supervisor shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking shall not be indicated upon any federal-aid or state highway within the city unless the state highway commission has determined by resolution or order entered in its minutes that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 2) 
Sec. 16-40. - Obedience to parking signs or markings. 
(a)  Upon those streets which have been signed or marked by the city traffic engineer for parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than in the place and manner indicated by such signs or markings or both. 
(b)  When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle between the prohibited hours specified within the block or upon any of the streets so signed. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 2) 
Sec. 16-41. - Standing or parking close to curb. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 3) 
Sec. 16-42. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever a vehicle is parked upon a street or highway outside of a business or residence district during the hours between one-half (1/2) hour after sunset and one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise, such vehicle shall be equipped with one (1) or more lamps which shall exhibit a white light on the roadway side visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the front of the vehicle and a red light visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear. 
(b)  Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 3) 
Sec. 16-43. - Unattended motor vehicle. 
(a)  No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key, and effectively setting the hand brake thereon and, when standing upon any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway. 
(b)  No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall leave any unattended children within the vehicle, nor shall any animal be left unattended without proper ventilation. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 3) 
Sec. 16-44. - Unlawful parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any vehicle registered in his name to be unlawfully parked as set out on this article. Proof of registration of a motor vehicle and proof of a violation of this article shall be construed as prima facie proof that the registered owner of such motor vehicle was the user or operator thereof at the time of the violation charge. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 7) 
Sec. 16-45. - Application; holidays enumerated. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply every day between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., except Thursday afternoons, Sundays and holidays; and provided, further, that within the meaning of this article the term "holiday" shall include the following days only: The first day of January, the fourth day of July, the first Monday in September, the twenty-fifth day of December, and the day designated and set aside by the President of the United States as a day of Thanksgiving. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 8) 
Sec. 16-46. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(a)  To cause, allow, permit or suffer any such vehicle registered in his name, or in his control or possession to be parked or stand overtime, or remain therein beyond the parking time limit prescribed for such space. 
(b)  To deface, injure, tamper with, or impair the usefulness of any parking sign installed under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 5) 
Sec. 16-47. - Records; citations; penalty for late payment. 
    It shall be the duty of the city police or any other person so named by the city council, to check the parking spaces and meters and report the violation of this article in the following manner: 
(a)  Keep an account of and report the number of each parking space which indicated that the vehicle had been parked in violation of any of the provisions of this article, the date and hour of such violation, the make and the state license number of such vehicle, and any other facts or knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
(b)  Attach to such vehicles notice stating that it has been parked in violation of this article and instructing the owner or operator to report at a certain designated time and place to the municipal court in the city, in regard to such violation. Each such owner or operator, may within forty-eight (48) hours of the time when such notice was attached to such vehicle, pay to the police department as a penalty for and in full satisfaction for such violation, the sum of two dollars ($2.00). The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment within forty-eight (48) hours shall render such owner or operator subject to punishment as provided in section 1-8, Violations-General penalty; continuing offense. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 5) 
Sec. 16-48. - Impounding vehicles. 
(a)  Members of the police department are authorized to remove a vehicle from a street or highway to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the police department, or otherwise maintained by the city under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct, or causeway, or in any tube or tunnel where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(2)  When a vehicle upon a highway is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the persons in charge of the vehicle are by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
(3)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(b)  Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street as authorized in this section and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle the name and address of the owner thereof, such officer shall immediately give or cause to be given notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor and of the place to which such vehicle has been removed. In the event any such vehicle is stored in a public garage, a copy of such notice shall be given to the proprietor of such garage. 
(c)  Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street under this section and does not know and is not able to ascertain the name of the owner, or for any other reason is unable to give notice to the owner as hereinbefore provided, and in the event the vehicle is not returned to the owner within a period of three (3) days, the officer shall immediately send or cause to be sent a written report of such removal by mail to the state department whose duty it is to register motor vehicles, and shall file a copy of such notice with the proprietor of any public garage in which the vehicle may be stored. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle; the date, time and place from which removed; the reasons for such removal; and name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(d)  Cost for removal of a vehicle and the storage thereof will be under the responsibility of the owner. No vehicle shall be removed until said costs have been paid in full. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 5) 
Secs. 16-49, 16-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLACES WHERE PARKING RESTRICTED OR PROHIBITED 

Sec. 16-51. - Adjacent to schools. 
(a)  The public works supervisor is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(b)  When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon that side of the street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Ord. No. 11-27-79, § 2) 
Sec. 16-52. - On narrow streets. 
(a)  The public works supervisor is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon any street, or upon one (1) side of any street when parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b)  When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 2) 
Sec. 16-53. - On one-way streets. 
    The public works supervisor is authorized to erect signs upon the left-hand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles, and when such signs are in place, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such left-hand side in violation of any such sign. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 2) 
Sec. 16-54. - On one-way roadways. 
    In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left-hand side of such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The public works supervisor is authorized to determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the left-hand side of any such one-way roadway and to erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 3) 
Sec. 16-55. - Specific areas of limited parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle for a period longer than fifteen (15) minutes in the six (6) parking spaces numbered by the city public works supervisor, numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6, located in front of the post office in the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle for a period longer than thirty (30) minutes in the four (4) parking spaces numbered by the city public works supervisor, numbered 89, 90, 91, 92, located in front of the Monroe County Library in the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle for a period longer than thirty (30) minutes in the sixteen (16) parking spaces numbered by the city public works supervisor, numbered 105, 106, 107, 108, 109, 110, 111, 112, 113, 114, 115, 116, 117, 118, 119, and 120, located along West Claiborne Street in the city. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle for a period longer than two (2) hours along the public streets or highways on a parking space numbered by the city public works supervisor in the city, except as provided in subsections (a), (b), and (c) above. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 3; Ord. of 3-3-87) 
Sec. 16-56. - All night parking. 
    No person, except physicians on emergency calls, shall park a vehicle on any street in the fire limits for a period of time longer than one (1) hour between those hours of the night which may hereafter be designated by the street superintendent. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 4) 
Sec. 16-57. - Parking near burning building. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than authorized personnel to park any motor vehicle within three hundred (300) feet of any building which is on fire. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 3) 
Sec. 16-58. - Prohibited parking; no signs necessary. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or a traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk or on any grass plot or paved area between the sidewalk and curb; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection except at intersections where traffic is controlled by a traffic officer or a traffic-control device; 
(7)  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign, or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of the safety zone, unless the public works supervisor has indicated a different length by signs or markings; 
(9)  Within twenty-five (25) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
(10)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of said entrance when properly signposted; 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel; 
(14)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(c)  The city public works supervisor is authorized to mark all prohibited or restricted parking places. It shall be unlawful to stand or park a vehicle in any place so marked, unless otherwise designated by official signs or markings, and then in strict accordance therewith. 
(d)  No person shall park any vehicle upon a street, in such manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(e)  No person shall park any vehicle within any alley in the city. 
(f)  No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying for sale; 
(2)  Holding or storing for sale; 
(3)  Washing, greasing or repairing, except repairs necessary by an emergency; 
(4)  Leaving, holding or storing in case of mechanical disability for a period of time in excess of twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 4) 
Sec. 16-59. - Parking in fire lanes. 
(a)  The fire chief of the city is hereby authorized to designate fire areas or fire zones on property devoted to public use including, but not by way of limitation, shopping centers, bowling alleys, drive-in theaters, churches, swimming pools and similar uses involving parking of a sufficient number of motor vehicles to make necessary such regulation for the protection of persons and property in case of fire or other emergencies. A fire area shall be established to ensure fire equipment and other emergency vehicles means of ingress and egress to such property and the buildings, persons, vehicles, fire hydrants, and stand pipes thereon in case of fire or other emergencies. 
(b)  The number, location, width, length, and markings of such areas shall be determined by the fire chief, subject to the authority of the city council to grant variances where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement will result in unnecessary hardship. 
(c)  It shall be lawful for any person to park in such fire areas or to otherwise obstruct such fire areas. 
(d)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 11-7-89; Ord. of 7-2-96; Ord. No. 2016-03-005, 3-1-16) 
Secs. 16-60-16-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LOADING AND UNLOADING 

Sec. 16-66. - Designation of loading zones. 
    The public works supervisor is authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the hours during which the provisions are applicable. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 6) 
Sec. 16-67. - Parking truck tractors, trailers, semi-trailers, etc., on streets prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person at any time in any public street, boulevard or avenue, within the corporate limits of the city to park, or cause or allow to be parked, any truck tractor or a trailer or a semi-trailer or any combination thereof, except for the purpose of loading or unloading. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 6; Ord. of 10-3-89) 
Sec. 16-68. - Standing in passenger curb loading zone. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three (3) minutes. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 6) 
Sec. 16-69. - Standing in freight curb loading zone. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during the hours the provisions applicable to such zone are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed thirty-six (36) minutes, without first obtaining a special permit from the chief of police. Where parking meters are installed in said loading zones, the manner and time of parking shall be governed by said meters. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 6) 
Sec. 16-70. - Bus stops and taxicabs stands. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized and required to establish bus stops and taxicab stands on such public streets in such places and in such manner as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop and taxicab stand shall be designated by appropriate signs or markings. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 6) 
Sec. 16-71. - Same-Required use in business districts. 
    The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop, or taxicab stand, respectively, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 6) 
Sec. 16-72. - Same-Prohibited use. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus, or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Ord. of 11-27-79, § 6) 
Sec. 16-73. - Parking spaces for the physically handicapped. 
(a)  The police chief of the city is hereby authorized to designate marked parking spaces for the exclusive parking of motor vehicles operated or occupied by the physically handicapped. 
(b)  Vehicles which bear the authorized handicapped insignia decal and which are operated or occupied by the physically handicapped are eligible to utilize those handicapped parking spaces created by this section. 
(c)  All permits so issued to such handicapped persons may be revoked or cancelled for abuse, misuse or unauthorized use by persons other than the holder of such permit. 
(d)  With the consent of the property owner, it is also authorized, in addition to the above, for the police chief of the city to designate certain parking spaces in privately owned parking areas to be posted as parking for the handicapped under the provisions of this section. The parking spaces so designated as such areas shall be subject to the same regulations as provided in this section. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person not displaying a permit as herein provided to park a vehicle in an area designated for handicapped parking. 
(f)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of a minimum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and up to a maximum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. of 10-17-89; Ord. of 7-2-96; Ord. No. 2016-02-004, 3-1-16; Ord. No. 2016-05-001, 5-3-16) 
Secs. 16-74-16-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PARKING VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 16-81. - Parking offense defined-Presumptive evidence. 
(a)  A parking offense is a violation of an ordinance, statute or regulation enacted by local authority to regulate and enforce the standing and parking of vehicles within the jurisdiction of the municipality. Authority is established by this division to include jurisdiction on certain private and public properties. 
(b)  Prima facie presumption shall be evidence that the registered owner of such unattended vehicle was the person who parked, placed or caused to be placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. The burden of proof shall be upon the current registered owner to show otherwise. 
(Ord. of 9-7-99, Art. I) 
Sec. 16-82. - Parking citations. 
(1)  Forms. Municipal parking citations shall be issued and served to the alleged offender who is in violation of an ordinance as specified in the offense section of this article. The parking citation form and procedure is hereby adopted pursuant to Rule 19(B) Alabama Rules of Judicial Administration. If a law enforcement officer or authorized public official chooses to cite the violator for a municipal ordinance parking violation listed in this subsection, the parking citation (ticket) illustrated in Appendix A [attached to the ordinance from which this section derived] shall be used. 
(2)  Procedure for issuance. 
(a)  Any law enforcement officer, or public official designated with authority, who views or has personal knowledge that a violation of municipal law as specified by this division is authorized to enforce that law by the issuance of a parking citation. The citation shall be affixed to the vehicle, or in cases where the offense is viewed when committed, delivered to the person in violation of such municipal ordinance (law). 
(b)  The officer or official who cites the offense shall transmit the original part of the citation to the court magistrate without unnecessary delay for accountability and summary disposition. 
(Ord. of 9-7-99, Art. II) 
Sec. 16-83. - Offenses, fines/penalties. 
(a)  Offenses-Fines. Any person found to be in violation of this division for the commission of an offense under this division, upon acknowledgment of guilt or administrative adjudication and finding of guilt, shall be punished in accordance with the following schedule of fines, which includes court costs: 
OFFENSE/SECTION FINE Parking double [-01] $5.00 Parking on wrong side of street [-02]  5.00 Parking in NO PARKING ZONE [-03]  5.00 Parking at fire hydrant [-04]  50.00 Parking in HANDICAPPED ZONE [-05]  50.00** Parking at expired meter [06]  4.00 Parking on railroad track [-07]  5.00 Parking in a LOADING ZONE [-08]  5.00 Parking in a FIRE LANE [-09]  50.00 Blocking an alley [-10]  5.00 Blocking an intersection [-11]  5.00 Blocking a driveway [-12]  5.00  
**$50.00 for the first offense, $200.00 for the second offense and $500.00 for the third and/or subsequent offenses. 
(2)  Mail-in procedure for payment. 
(a)  The violator of a parking offense may choose to plead guilty and pay the fine by mailing in the full amount to the municipal court clerk/magistrate. Payment must be received before the date of the hearing. A hearing date can be set by contacting the municipal court clerk/magistrate. 
(b)  Payment must be in the form of a money order or cashier's check to be submitted by mail. The signed citation should be included with the payment. Payment may be made in person to the municipal court clerk/magistrate in the form of cash. 
(3)  Failure to comply with citation-Additional penalty. 
(a)  If a violator does not appear in response to a citation affixed to such motor vehicle before the date of the hearing, the owner of the motor vehicle to which the citation was affixed shall be notified by letter informing him of the violation and warning him that in the event such letter is disregarded for a period of more than ten (10) days, a complaint will be filed for failure to appear and a warrant of arrest will be issued. Upon the arrest under this section, the arrested person shall be bailable as a matter of right and released on his or her personal recognizance subject to the condition that he or she must appear in court as directed. 
(b)  The fine amount may be increased upon adjudication of the citation if the violator does not appear for a hearing or the payment does reach the municipal court clerk/magistrate's office before the date set for the hearing. 
(Ord. of 9-7-99, Art. III) 
Sec. 16-84. - Conflicts. 
    This division is to be held in pari materia with all other provisions of the Monroeville Code related to parking, stopping and standing. Any ordinance heretofore adopted by the city council of the City of Monroeville, Alabama, which is in direct conflict with this division is hereby repealed to the extent of such conflict. 
(Ord. of 9-7-99, Art. IV) 
Chapter 17 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Required sewer connections, § 11-40 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Sewage treatment plant operation. 
(a)  Position created. The position of sewage treatment plant operator is hereby created. 
(b)  Qualifications. The minimum qualifications for employment in this position shall be a high school degree, or equivalent thereof, and a demonstrated aptitude or understanding of mechanical and electrical equipment. 
(c)  Certification, school attendance. The position so created shall be considered as temporary until the operator has been certified by the Alabama Board of Examiners for Sewage Treatment Plant Operators; and that the applicant selected be required to attend the earliest scheduled Short Course School for Sewage Treatment Plant Operators, University of Alabama, the cost of such schooling being defrayed by the city. 
(d)  Superior; reports. The operator shall be directly responsible to the mayor, and shall submit reports daily, through the city clerk, relating to the performance and conditions of the facilities under his jurisdiction. 
(e)  Professional association membership. The operator shall be required to apply for membership in the Alabama Water and Pollution Control Association, and, if accepted, his membership costs shall be defrayed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 78, §§ 1-6, 11-28-67) 
Sec. 17-2. - Water works plant and system franchise-Granting. 
    There is hereby granted to the water works board of the City of Monroeville, a corporation organized under the provisions of Title 37, sections 394 to 402, inclusive, of the Code of Alabama of 1940, as amended, the right, privilege, authority and franchise to acquire, own, maintain, construct, enlarge and operate a water works plant and system in the City of Monroeville, Alabama, for the purpose of supplying water to said city and the inhabitants thereof, and the consent of said city is hereby given to said grantee to use the streets, avenues, alleys and public ways and public places of said town for the construction, maintenance and operation of such water works plant and system. 
(Ord. of 11-13-45, § 1) 
Sec. 17-3. - Same-Authority conferred. 
    The grantee is hereby granted the right, privilege and authority at any time and from time to time, and without any requirement as to permit or fee therefor, to extend its mains over any streets, avenues, alleys and public ways and public places in said city for the purpose of enlarging and extending its said system. 
(Ord. of 11-13-45, § 2) 
Sec. 17-4. - Same-Street restoration. 
    The grantee shall, and by accepting this franchise agrees, that it will upon making any excavations of the streets, avenues, alleys, public ways and public places of said city for the purpose of constructing, maintaining or operating said system, restore the surface or paving at the point of such excavations in substantially the same condition as before such work was done, all as promptly as may be practicable and within a reasonable length of time thereafter. 
(Ord. of 11-13-45, § 3) 
Sec. 17-5. - Same-Assignment. 
    The rights, privileges, franchise and authority hereby granted may be exercised by the grantee or any successors and assigns of the grantee, all subject nevertheless to the conditions and obligations herein contained. 
(Ord. of 11-13-45, § 4) 
Sec. 17-6. - Gas franchise-Granting. 
    The municipality hereby grants to the Conecuh-Monroe Counties Gas District, its successors and assigns (hereinafter referred to as the "district"), the right, privilege, authority and franchise to acquire, construct, own, maintain, enlarge, extend, improve and operate a gas system in the municipality (including facilities for the manufacture of gas and for the transmission and distribution of manufactured and natural gas, either or both), for the purpose of supplying gas to the municipality and the surrounding territory and the inhabitants thereof and to use the streets, avenues, alleys and public ways and places in said municipality for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 31, § 1, 7-18-61) 
Sec. 17-7. - Same-Authority conferred.
