    Persons who have filed incomplete applications will be notified in writing by the city that the application is deficient and the nature of such deficiency and will be given forty-five (45) days or within such extended period as allowed by the city to respond in writing. If no written response is received from the applicant in the time frame specified by the city, the city shall submit the application to the Alabama Department of Environmental Management with a recommendation that it be denied and notify the applicant in writing of such action. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(18)) 
Sec. 17-124. - Evaluation of SID applications. 
(a)  All SID permit applications will be dealt with in accordance with procedures enumerated in the memorandum of agreement executed between the City of Monroeville and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. The city may recommend to the Alabama Department of Environmental Management that the SID permit applications require any of the following items: 
(1)  Pretreatment requirements; 
(2)  The average and maximum wastewater constituents and characteristics; 
(3)  Limits on rate and time of discharge or requirements for flow regulation and equalization. 
(4)  Requirements for installation of inspection and sampling facilities; 
(5)  Specifications for monitoring programs which may include sampling locations, frequency and method of sampling, number, types and standards for tests and reporting schedule; 
(6)  Requirements for submission of technical reports or discharge reports; 
(7)  Requirements for maintaining records relating to wastewater discharge; 
(8)  Mean and maximum mass emission rates, or other appropriate limits when incompatible pollutants (as set forth in division 2 of this article) are proposed or present in the user's wastewater discharge; 
(9)  Other conditions as deemed appropriate by the city to insure compliance with this article or other applicable ordinance, law, or regulation; 
(10)  A reasonable compliance schedule will be required to insure the industrial user's compliance with pretreatment requirements; 
(11)  Requirements for the installation of facilities to prevent and control accidental discharge or "spills" at the user's premises; 
(12)  Mass limitations where dilution is used to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements or in other cases where the imposition of mass limitations are deemed appropriate. 
(b)  The user shall design any necessary facility, and submit detailed design plans and operating procedures to the city and to state, and federal agencies having jurisdiction. The city shall review and comment on said plans within forty-five (45) calendar days and recommend to the user any change it deems appropriate. Upon comment by the city and approval by state and federal agencies of plans as specified above, the user shall secure such building, electrical, plumbing, or other permits as may be required by applicable codes and proceed to construct any necessary facilities and establish such operating procedures as are required within the time provided in the user's SID permit. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(19)) 
Sec. 17-125. - Applicant's notification of proposed SID permit conditions and objection procedures. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a draft SID permit, the applicant shall have thirty (30) calendar days to review same and file written objections with the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. 
(b)  Within fifteen (15) calendar days of receipt of an applicant's request or written objections, the city may schedule a meeting between itself, the applicant, and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, for the purpose of resolving the disputed SID permit issues. 
(c)  If an applicant files no written objection to the draft SID permit proposed by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, or a subsequent agreement is reached concerning the same, issuance of the permit will be in accordance with the memorandum of agreement executed between the City of Monroeville and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(20)) 
Sec. 17-126. - Permission to discharge. 
    Issuance of a SID permit by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management shall constitute permission by the city to discharge into the city's sewer system, under the terms and conditions as enumerated in the SID permit. All users not required to operate under an SID permit or who currently contribute wastewater other than normal domestic sewage or discharge in excess of seven hundred (700) gpd shall comply with the provisions of division 6 of this article. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(21)) 
Sec. 17-127. - Compliance schedule and reporting requirements. 
(a)  Compliance with National Categorical Pretreatment Standards for existing sources subject to such standards or for existing sources which hereafter became subject to such standards shall be within three (3) years following promulgation of the standards unless a shorter compliance time is specified in the standard compliance with National Categorical Pretreatment Standards for new sources shall be required upon promulgation of the standard. The city shall attempt to notify in writing any user whom it has cause to believe is subject to a National Categorical Pretreatment Standard upon promulgation of such federal regulations, but any failure of the city in this regard shall not relieve the user of the duty of complying with such national pretreatment standards. 
(b)  The following conditions shall apply to the schedule required by sections 17-122 and 17-124 of this division: 
(1)  The schedule shall contain increments of progress in the form of calendar dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment facilities for the industrial user to meet the applicable pretreatment standards (e.g. hiring an engineer, completing preliminary plans completing final plans, executing contract for major components, commencing construction, completing construction, etc.). 
(2)  No increment referred to in subsection (1) of this section shall exceed nine (9) months. 
(3)  Not later than fourteen (14) days following each date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the industrial user shall submit a progress report to the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management including, as a minimum, whether or not it complied with the increment of progress to be met on such date and, if not, the date on which it expects to comply with this increment of progress, the reason for the delay, and steps being taken by the industrial user to return the construction to the schedule established. In no event shall more than nine (9) months elapse between such progress reports to the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. 
(4)  Within ninety (90) days following the date for final compliance with applicable pretreatment standards or, in the case of a new source, following commencement of the introduction of wastewater into the POTW any industrial user subject to pretreatment standards and requirements shall submit to the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management a report indicating the nature and concentration of all pollutants in the discharge from the regulated process which are limited by pretreatment standards and requirements and the average and maximum daily flow for these process units in the industrial user which are limited by such pretreatment standards or requirements. The report shall state whether the applicable pretreatment standards or requirements are being met on a consistent basis and, if not, what additional operation and maintenance procedure or pretreatment is necessary to bring the industrial user into compliance with the applicable pretreatment standards or requirements. This statement shall be signed by an authorized representative of the industrial user as defined in division 1 of this article and certified by a professional engineer registered in the State of Alabama. 
(5)  Any industrial user subject to a pretreatment standard after the compliance date of such pretreatment standard, or, in the case of a new source, after commencement of the discharge into the POTW, shall submit to the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management during the months of June and December unless required more frequently in the pretreatment standard or by the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, a report indicating the nature and concentration of pollutants in the effluent which are limited by such pretreatment standards. In addition this report shall include a record of all daily flows which during the reporting period exceeded the average daily flow reported in subsection 17-122(4) of this division. At the discretion of the city or the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, as applicable, and in consideration of such factors as local high or low flow rates, holidays, budget cycles, etc. the city or the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, as applicable, may agree to alter the months during which the above reports are to be submitted. 
(6)  If mass limitations have been imposed on the industrial user's discharge, the report required by subsection (b)(1) of this section shall indicate the mass of pollutants regulated by pretreatment standards in the effluent of the industrial user. 
(7)  The frequency of monitoring effluent discharge shall be prescribed by the applicable pretreatment standard. All analyses shall be performed in accordance with procedures established by the Environmental Protection Agency under the provisions of Section 304(h) of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1314(h)) and contained in 40 CFR Part 136 and amendments thereto or with any other test procedures approved by the Environmental Protection Agency. Sampling shall be performed in accordance with the techniques approved by the Environmental Protection Agency. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(22)) 
Sec. 17-128. - Maintenance of records. 
    Any industrial user subject to the reporting requirements established in this division shall maintain records of all information resulting from any monitoring activities required by this article. Such records shall include for all samples: 
(1)  The date; exact place, method, and time of sampling; and the names of the persons taking the samples; 
(2)  The dates analyses were performed; 
(3)  Who performed the analyses; 
(4)  The analytical techniques/methods used; and 
(5)  The results of such analyses. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(23)) 
Sec. 17-129. - Retention of records. 
    Any industrial user subject to the reporting requirement established in this division shall be required to retain for a minimum of five (5) years any records of monitoring activities and results (whether or not such monitoring activities are required by this section) and shall make such records available for inspection and copying by the city, the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, or the EPA. This period of retention shall be extended during the course of any unresolved litigation regarding the industrial user or when requested by the city, the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, or the EPA. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(24)) 
Sec. 17-130. - Confidentiality. 
    Any records, reports, or information obtained in accordance with these rules and regulations are intended to be used to determine applicable effluent limitations, toxic conditions, pretreatment requirements, or permit conditions and shall be available to the public except that upon a showing satisfactory to the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management by any person, records, reports, or information, or particular part-thereof (other than effluent data) to which the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management has access to under this article, if made public would divulge methods or processes entitled to protection as trade secrets of such person. The city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management shall consider such record, report, or information or particular portion thereof confidential in accordance with the purposes of this division, except that such record, report, or information may be disclosed to officers, employees, or authorized representatives of the State of Alabama or the United States concerned with carrying out the provisions of the Clean Water Act or when relevant in any proceeding under these rules and regulations or other applicable laws. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(25)) 
Sec. 17-131. - Duration of permits. 
    SID permits shall be issued for a period of five (5) years provided that original permits may be issued for a period between three (3) and five (5) years for the administrative convenience of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management so as to stagger the renewal dates of the permits. Not withstanding the foregoing, users becoming subject to a national pretreatment standard shall apply for new permits on the effective date of such national pretreatment standards. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(26)) 
Sec. 17-132. - Permit renewal. 
    A user must apply in writing to the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management for a renewal permit within the period of time not more than ninety (90) days and not less than thirty (30) days prior to expiration of the current permit. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(27)) 
Sec. 17-133. - Permit modifications. 
(a)  Limitations or conditions of a permit are subject to modification or change as such changes may become necessary due to changes in applicable water quality standards, changes in the NPDES permit, changes in division 2 of this article, changes in other applicable law or regulation, or for other just cause. Any proposed change or new condition in a permit shall include a provision for a reasonable time schedule for compliance and shall be made known to the user. Upon receipt of the draft modification, the user shall have thirty (30) calendar days to review same and file written objections with the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. 
(1)  Within fifteen (15) calendar days of receipt of a user's request or written objection, the city may schedule a meeting between itself, the applicant and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management for the purpose of resolving the disputed SID permit change. 
(2)  The city reserves the right to impose a total ban or limitation on any compounds it feels are harmful to the sewer system, regardless of whether or not limitation for these compounds are listed in the SID issued by ADEM. 
(3)  If a user files no written objection to the draft modification, or a subsequent agreement is reached concerning the same, the Alabama Department of Environmental Management shall incorporate said modification into the user's SID permit in accordance with the memorandum of agreement between the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. 
(b)  Any significant change in the nature or volume of the wastewater constituents of a permitted user shall be reported to the city and may require the user to be subject to a modified SID permit. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(20), Art. 4(28)) 
Sec. 17-134. - Transfer of a permit. 
    SID permits are issued to a specific user for a specific operation. A SID permit shall not be reassigned or transferred or sold to a new owner, new user, or for different premises. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 4(29)) 
Secs. 17-135-17-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - INSPECTIONS, MONITORING, AND ENTRY 

Sec. 17-151. - General. 
(a)  The city and/or the Alabama Department of Environmental Management shall require any nondomestic primary or significant industrial user, as defined by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, to establish and maintain such records, make such reports, install, use, and maintain such monitoring equipment or methods, (including where appropriate) biological monitoring methods, sample such effluents (in accordance with such methods, at such intervals, and in such manner as the city and the Alabama Department of Environmental Management shall prescribe), and provide such other information as they may reasonably require. 
(b)  Further, the city, its representatives, the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, and the EPA shall have a right of entry to all properties for purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of these rules and regulations and may at reasonable times have access to and copy any records, inspect any monitoring equipment or method required above, and sample any effluents which the owner or operator is required to sample under division 4 of this article. Failure to permit entry in accordance with the above conditions shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable as provided in Section 1-8 [sic] of this Code. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 5(30)) 
Sec. 17-152. - Monitoring facilities. 
    Industrial wastewater disposal connections, where pretreatment is required by the city to satisfactorily carry out its inspection and monitoring responsibilities, may be required to have a control manhole or equivalent with a city-approved automatic flow proportional refrigerated sampler and flow measuring device with continuous recorder and totalizer. Such a facility will be required to enable observation, measurement and sampling of all waste discharged to the POTW. Such control facility shall be constructed at such location and in such a manner as may be directed by the superintendent. Such a facility shall be installed by the industrial user discharging to the POTW without cost to the city. The city shall arrange for maintenance of the facility, collect the samples and be responsible for testing of samples. The city, in a manner to be prescribed, shall be reimbursed by the user for any expense incurred in the above mentioned maintenance, sampling, testing and any other related expenses required to make facility safe, accessible, and in proper operating condition. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 5(31)) 
Sec. 17-153. - Responsibility. 
(a)  While performing the necessary work on private properties as indicated above, the superintendent or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company. 
(b)  The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a fully negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Ord. of 4-20-(2), Art. 5(32)) 
Secs. 17-154-17-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SANITARY DISCHARGE PERMIT 

Sec. 17-161. - Application for existing users. 
    All users who currently contribute wastewater, other than normal domestic sewage, a discharge volume greater than seven hundred (700) gallons per day and not required to operate under an SID permit shall submit a sanitary sewer discharge permit application and copy of the existing City of Monroeville discharge permit within thirty (30) calendar days of receiving written notification from the city. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 6(33)) 
Sec. 17-162. - Application for new users. 
    All new users who wish to contribute wastewater other than normal domestic sewage or who have a discharge volume greater than seven hundred (700) gallons per day and are not required to operate under an SID permit shall submit a sanitary sewer discharge permit application for the purpose of connecting the facility to the POTW. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 6(34)) 
Sec. 17-163. - Applicant's notification of proposed sanitary sewer discharge permit; objection procedures. 
(a)  Upon completion of its evaluation, the city shall issue or deny a sanitary sewer discharge permit within thirty (30) calendar days of receipt of the application. 
(b)  If denied, written notice shall be provided which specifies the reasons for denial. 
(1)  Said notice shall also set a time and place for a hearing, not to exceed fourteen (14) calendar days from date of service of the notice. At said hearing, applicant may appear and be afforded a full opportunity to be heard. 
(2)  The hearing shall be conducted by the city's superintendent at a date and a time as specified in the notice. At said hearing, user shall be allowed to be represented by anyone of his choosing, user shall also have the right to produce any evidence he deems relevant. The city's superintendent shall hear such other evidence as he deems relevant to the issues. The city superintendent shall make a written decision within ten (10) days from the date of said hearing. Written notice of said decision shall be served on the user or his designated representative within ten (10) days from the date of the decision. Said decision shall set forth what action the city will take and the reasons therefor. 
(3)  Any applicant, aggrieved by the decision of the city's superintendent, shall have the right to appeal to the City of Monroeville. The appeal must be filed by the user, with the clerk, within ten (10) days from the date of service of the city superintendent's decision made on the user. Said appeal shall be in writing. The timely filing of the appeal by the user shall stay the decision of the city superintendent, no action shall be taken on the city superintendent's decision, and the appeal to the city shall be de novo. However, the appeal shall not stay any civil or criminal action initiated by the city against the user. The clerk shall set the appeal for a public hearing before the City of Monroeville. Said hearing shall be held no later than ten (10) days from the date of the filing of the appeal with the clerk. At said public hearing, the user may appear and shall be provided an opportunity to be heard. The City of Monroeville may require the superintendent or any other employee of the city to also appear and be heard by the city. The City of Monroeville shall render a decision by resolution within ten (10) days from the date of said hearing before the city. A certified copy of said resolution shall be served on the user within ten (10) days from the date of the decision by the city. 
(c)  If the permit is issued and applicant objects to the permit's conditions, applicant may object through the procedures enumerated above in subsections (b)(1) through (3). 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 6(35)) 
Sec. 17-164. - Reporting requirements. 
    Any significant change in the nature or volume of the wastewater constituents of a permitted user shall be reported to the city in a timely fashion and may require the user to apply for a revised sanitary sewer discharge permit. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 6(36)) 
Sec. 17-165. - Duration of permits. 
    Sewer system discharge permits shall be issued for an indefinite time period provided all requirements of these rules and regulations continue to be met. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 6(37)) 
Sec. 17-166. - Transfer of permit. 
    Sewer system discharge permits are issued to a specific user for a specific operation. A sewer system discharge permit shall not be sold, reassigned, or transferred to a new owner, new user, or for different premises. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 6(38)) 
Secs. 17-167-17-174. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - DETERMINATION OF WASTEWATER VOLUME 

Sec. 17-175. - Wastewater volume. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided, the volume of wastewater delivered to the POTW will be considered the same as the quantity of water purchased from and metered by the city. If the volume of water delivered to the POTW is greater or less than the volume of water purchased from the city, the user shall make known to the city such differences. If differences do exist, it shall be the obligation of the user to install city-approved meters or other devices to determine the portion or quantity of wastewater delivered to the POTW. 
(b)  The city may consider establishing a constant ratio, factor, or percentage to be applied to the metered water quantity delivered by the water system in order to determine the waste delivered by the industry. Determining, as well as justifying, the factor to the city will be the responsibility of the user. The value of this factor may be periodically reviewed for accuracy by the city. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 7(39)) 
Secs. 17-176-17-179. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - FEES, CHARGES, PENALTIES 

Sec. 17-180. - User charges. 
Monthly base charge ..... $ 3.00 
Usage charge, per 100 C.F. ..... 0.79 
Commercial/industrial: Surcharge for all waste containing more than 200 mg/l BOD, or 200 mg/l SS, per pound, unless operating under a separate sewer use agreement ..... 0.65 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 8(40)) 
Sec. 17-181. - Industrial waste surcharge elements. 
    A waste surcharge may be assessed against any industry or large user (a flow of greater than seven hundred (700) gallons per day) in the city's service area whose wastewater characteristics exceed the following normal wastewater strengths unless that industry or large user has a separate sewer use agreement: 
BOD 200 mg/l Suspended solids (SS) 200 mg/l Grease (animal and vegetable fats and oils) 50 mg/l Oil and grease (mineral) 50 mg/l  
    At the discretion of the city and at such times when data has been compiled and established, additional or modified surcharge elements shall be imposed. Such surcharges shall be based upon the higher cost of treatment of the pollutant. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 8(41)) 
Sec. 17-182. - Septic tank pumping trucks. 
(a)  All persons owning vacuum or "septic tank" pump trucks or other liquid waste transport trucks are prohibited from any discharge, directly or indirectly, of wastewater into the POTW or the city sewerage system, unless they first have applied for and received a discharge operation permit from the superintendent. All applicants for a discharge operation permit shall complete such forms as required by the superintendent, pay appropriate fees, and agree in writing to abide by the provisions of this division and any special conditions or regulations established by the superintendent. The owners of such vehicles shall affix and display the permit number on the side of each vehicle used for such purposes. Such permits shall be valid for a period of one (1) year from date of issuance, provided that such permit shall be subject to revocation by the superintendent for violation of any provision of this division or reasonable regulation established by the superintendent. Such permits shall be limited to the discharge of wastewater which has none of the prohibited wastes enumerated in division 2 of this article. The superintendent shall designate the locations and times where such trucks may be discharged, and may refuse to accept any truckload of waste at his absolute discretion where it appears that the waste could interfere with the effective operation of the POTW. 
(b)  No person shall discharge any other holding tank waste, including recreational vehicles, into the POTW unless he shall have applied for and have been issued a permit by the superintendent. Such user shall pay any applicable charges or fees therefor, and shall comply with the conditions of the permit issued by the superintendent. 
(c)  A treatment fee shall be paid annually on the date of permit issuance. This fee shall cover the cost of providing treatment for domestic sewage waste discharged during the preceding year by the permit applicant. Fees shall be paid to and permits issued by the City of Monroeville. 
(d)  Septic tank waste shall be discharged to the POTW only at the designated manholes located at the wastewater treatment plant. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 8(42)) 
Sec. 17-183. - Miscellaneous fees. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this section to provide for the recovery or costs from the users of the city's wastewater disposal system for the implementation of the program established herein. The applicable charges or fees shall be set forth by the city's schedule of charges and fees. 
(b)  Charges and fees. The city may establish charges and fees when necessary which may include: 
(1)  Fees for monitoring, inspections, and surveillance procedures shall cover all costs incurred by the superintendent. 
(2)  Fees for holding tank haulers shall be established by the superintendent. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 8(43)) 
Secs. 17-184-17-189. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 17-190. - Damage to POTW. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any portion of the POTW. Any person violating the provision shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable pursuant to the Code of the City of Monroeville subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct, (Affrays, a Misdemeanor, Section 1979-8 of Code [sic]). 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(44)) 
Sec. 17-191. - Validity. 
    All resolutions, ordinances, parts of resolutions, or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(45)) 
Sec. 17-192. - Severability. 
    If any provision, paragraph, work, section or article of these rules and regulations is invalidated by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions, paragraphs, words, sections, and chapters shall not be affected and shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(46)) 
Sec. 17-193. - Noncontractuality. 
    Neither these rules and regulations nor any permission or approval granted hereunder shall be considered or construed as a contract by the city and any person. The city hereby expressly reserves the right to amend, change, or repeal these rules and regulations at any time. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(47)) 
Sec. 17-194. - Exceeding capacity of POTW. 
(a)  If the service applied for cannot be furnished in accordance with city, state, and federal rules and regulations and if the designed sewerage system capacity is exceeded there shall be no liability of/or by the city to the applicant for such services. 
(b)  The city may, at its discretion, investigate expansion to its POTW for the express purpose of satisfying the needs of a new customer or the increased capacity requirements of an existing customer. Appropriate costs assessed to the customer would be determined by the city covering arrangements for such service. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(48)) 
Sec. 17-195. - Remoteness to existing interceptor. 
    The city may deny and not be liable for service to a new customer if the customer's point of discharge will be at a distance considered to be prohibitive by the city for connection to the closest sizeable city sewer interceptor. Extension of such interceptor may be arranged, if technically feasible, at a cost to the customer unless public funding is available to defray part of such cost and the time element is acceptable. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(49)) 
Sec. 17-196. - Sewer extensions. 
    The city may accept wastewater from unincorporated areas that lie outside of the city limits only on an individual basis when specifically approved by the sewer superintendent and/or city council. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(50)) 
Sec. 17-197. - Inspection of connections. 
    No industrial or commercial sewer service with or without a control and/or inspection manhole shall be connected until the plumbing and connections incident thereto shall have been inspected and approved by the city. The sewer service connection shall be inspected and approved by the city. Inspector before any underground portion of the sewer service is covered. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(51)) 
Sec. 17-198. - Interruption of service. 
    The city shall not be liable for any damage resulting from failure of any sewer main, service pipes, or valve; or by discontinuing the operation of its wastewater collection, treatment and sewerage facilities for repair, extensions, or connections; or from the accidental failure of the wastewater collection system, or treatment and disposal facilities; or from any cause whatsoever. In cases of emergency, the city shall have the right to restrict the use of its wastewater collection, treatment, and disposal facilities in any reasonable manner for the protection of the city and its sewerage system. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(52)) 
Sec. 17-199. - Discontinuance of service-Refusal to connect service. 
    The city shall, after written notice, have the right to discontinue service, to revoke a permit for service, or to refuse to render service, for a violation of, or a failure to comply with these rules and regulations, or for the nonpayment of any obligation due to the city's sewerage system. Discontinuance of service by the city for any causes stated in these rules and regulations shall not release the customer from liability for service already received or from liability for payments that thereafter became due under the billing provisions or other provisions of the customer's agreement. The city shall have the right to refuse to render service to any applicant whenever the applicant or any member of the industry, company or firm to which service is to be furnished, is in default in the payment of any obligation to the city or has heretofore had his service disconnected because of a violation of the rules and regulations of these rules and regulations. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(53)) 
Sec. 17-200. - Use and maintenance of sewer laterals. 
(a)  Sewer laterals that have been previously used but have been abandoned due to the razing of building structures may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the city, to meet all requirements of these rules and regulations. All others must be sealed to the satisfaction of the city. Each individual, commercial or industrial user of the sewerage facilities of the city shall be entirely responsible for the maintenance private lateral which extends from the edge of the city's street right of way or easement to the private premises. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of all property owners that demolish or move existing buildings to preserve the location and integrity of sewer laterals, and to report this information to the city. The location of the sewer lateral shall be marked for locating by metal detector, and also marked on a property map. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(54)) 
Sec. 17-201. - Grease, oil, and sand interceptors (traps). 
(a)  Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when in the opinion of the superintendent they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. Such interceptors shall be required of, but not limited to restaurants, carwashes, and nursing homes. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(b)  The owner of each interceptor shall furnish the superintendent with documentation of periodic inspection and cleaning. Frequency of reporting this information to the city shall be as required by the superintendent. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(55)) 
Sec. 17-202. - Control manhole. 
    When required by the sewer superintendent, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(56)) 
Sec. 17-203. - Tests by standard methods. 
(a)  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in these rules and regulations shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater published by the American Public Health Association, or by approved EPA procedures, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole. In the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards of life, limb, and property. 
(b)  The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four (24) composites of all outfalls; whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 9(57)) 
Secs. 17-204-17-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - DOMESTIC SEWAGE PROVISIONS 

Sec. 17-216. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within Monroeville or in any area under the jurisdiction of, said city, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the City of Monroeville, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of these rules and regulations. 
(c)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within City of Monroeville and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer within the city, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of these rules and regulations, within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within two hundred (200) feet of the property line. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 10(58)) 
Sec. 17-217. - Private sewage disposal. 
    The disposal of sewage by means other than the use of the available sanitary sewage system shall be in accordance with local county and state law. The disposal of sewage by private disposal systems shall be permissible only in those instances where normal gravity service from the sanitary sewage system is not available, or found to be the cause of nuisance or damage to a resident. Alternative septic tank installations, such as "mound systems", are prohibited where location of public sanitary sewer permits owner to discharge waste by privately owned pump. Operation and maintenance of such pump and piping within owners property is the responsibility of the property owners. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 10(59)) 
Sec. 21-218. - Building sewers and connections. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent. 
(b)  There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: (a) for residential and commercial service, and (b) for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city. A permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. The amount of the fees shall be as set by the city. 
(c)  All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(d)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one (1) building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one (1) building sewer, or at discretion of superintendent to avoid excessive costs and damages to public streets and utilities. 
(e)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of these rules and regulations. 
(f)  All building sewers shall be provided with a clean out at the property line nearest the main sewer. 
(g)  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(h)  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(i)  No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(j)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and the WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. All pertinent OSHA requirements shall be met in the construction of sewers and connections. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the superintendent before installation. 
(k)  The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the superintendent when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent or his representative. 
(l)  All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 10(60)) 
Sec. 17-219. - Use of the public sewers. 
    Use of the public sewers is restricted to the handling of domestic sewage only. Restrictions for nonsewage neutral waters are listed under section 17-83(a) of this article (stormwaters, yard waters, etc.) and general restrictions are listed under section 17-81. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 10(61)) 
Secs. 17-220-17-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - EXCEPTIONS 

Sec. 17-226. - pH. 
    Section 17-81(2) prohibits entry into the city's sewer system of wastes having a pH above 9.0. However, if the waste is to be conducted by an industrial interceptor directly into the POTW treatment facility which was designed to accept and treat wastes of very high pH, then it is the option of the city to consider such application for service and make arrangements for the proper permit covering such installation and service. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 11(62)) 
Sec. 17-227. - Temperature. 
    Section 17-81(5) prohibits entry into the city's sewer system of wastes having a temperature above one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit. However, if arrangements are made to provide an industrial interceptor directly to the POTW treatment facility for such wastes above one hundred four degrees (104) degrees Fahrenheit, the city has the option to consider such application for service and allow the issuance of the proper permit subject to other agency restrictions. 
(Ord. of 4-20-99(2), Art. 11(63)) 
Chapter 17.5 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 17.5-1-17.5-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WRECKERS AND TOWING SERVICES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Feb. 2, 1988, enacted provisions pertaining to wreckers and towing services. Such provisions did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion as Art. II, §§ 17.5-21-17.5-29, has been at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Business license schedule, § 5-20. 

Sec. 17.5-21. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Call means each request for services of an operator resulting in an operator being able to perform services. 
    Department means the Monroeville Alabama Police Department. 
    Officer means any Monroeville Police Department Officer. 
    Operator means any person owning or operating a wrecker or towing service, including any employee of any person owning or operating a wrecker or towing service. 
    Rotation log means a list of holders of current wrecker permits issued by the Monroeville Police Department granting authority for operation of a wrecker or towing service which governs the manner in which services may be alternated among operators. 
    Tow means: 
(1)  The pulling of a wrecked, damaged, or disabled vehicle which is otherwise incapable of self-propulsion away from the scene of an accident or traffic tie-up; and 
(2)  The pulling of a vehicle any time an officer deems it necessary to protect the public safety and/or personal property. 
    Wrecker of towing service means any motor vehicle capable of pulling or towing any wrecked, damaged or disabled motor vehicle otherwise incapable of self-propulsion. 
    Wrecker permit means the wrecker permit issued by the Monroeville Police Department. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88) 
Sec. 17.5-22. - Facilities. 
    Each operator shall have space available which must be able to accommodate a minimum of ten (10) vehicles, and enclosed by a six-foot chain link fence and gate for properly accommodating and protecting all disabled motor vehicles and their contents against damage or theft. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88) 
Sec. 17.5-23. - Equipment requirements. 
(a)  Every wrecker to be placed on the Monroeville Police Department rotation system shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  A minimum of three-fourth-ton factory recommended capacity with dual wheels. Dummy dual wheels are prohibited. 
(2)  A power or hand-operated winch, winch line, and boom with a factory rated lifting capacity or a tested capacity of not less than four thousand (4,000) pounds single line capacity. 
(3)  One (1) "sling" and "stay-bar" or other type of device capable of protecting the disabled vehicle while being towed. 
(4)  There shall be placed on each wrecker as standard equipment: 
a.  Tow bars. 
b.  Safety chains. 
c.  One (1) or more dry chemical, B.C. rating, fire extinguishers having a minimum of twenty (20) pounds' total capacity. 
d.  One (1) pry bar or wrecker bar capable of prying open doors. 
e.  One (1) push type broom. 
f.  One (1) axe. 
g.  One (1) shovel. 
h.  Warning devices, applicable to trucks, as required in Sections 220 and 221, Chapter 5 of Title 32 of the Code of Alabama, capable of protecting the scene of an accident by day or night. 
i.  At least one (1) amber, rotating or flashing beacon visible from three hundred sixty degrees (360;deg;). In addition, each vehicle shall have an emergency flasher system capable of emitting two (2) amber lights to the front and two (2) red lights to the rear of the vehicle and which shall flash simultaneously. All lighting systems must be visible for a minimum of five hundred (500) feet. 
(b)  Each wrecker business shall have a minimum of one "dolly" available for use by its wreckers. The name of the wrecker business shall be permanently affixed to said dolly. 
(c)  The name, address and telephone number of the wrecker company [shall] be permanently affixed and displayed on both doors. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88) 
Sec. 17.5-24. - Records. 
(a)  Each operator shall maintain a record system covering all services performed in pulling or towing all vehicles in conjunction with the Monroeville Police Department rotation system, and such records shall include the following: 
(1)  The date and time the operator was contacted and requested to perform his service. 
(2)  The name of the person requesting the services. 
(3)  The location of the vehicle. 
(4)  A description of the towed vehicle, including license tag and identification number. 
(5)  The owner or driver of the vehicle, if known. 
(6)  The service charge and fees. 
(b)  All records required herein must be available for inspection by the Monroeville Police Department. 
(c)  The operator shall maintain the aforementioned records for the current calendar year and the calendar year immediately prior to the current calendar year. 
(d)  A record of all abandoned motor vehicles is to be maintained by the wrecker company and any abandoned motor vehicle sold or disposed of shall be done in accordance with Chapter 13, Title 32, Code of Alabama. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88) 
Sec. 17.5-25. - Insurance. 
(a)  Each operator, from the time he moves or otherwise makes contact with any vehicle to be towed, assumed liability for injury to persons, damage to property, fire or theft resulting from the operator's negligent acts. 
(b)  Each operator shall maintain a valid bond or insurance policy issued by a surety or an insurance company currently authorized to issue bonds or policies of insurance covering risks in the State of Alabama. The aforementioned bond or insurance policy shall protect the public against loss of life, bodily injury to person, and damage to property in the following amounts: 
Casualty coverage: 
(1)  Not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for bodily injury to any one (1) person. 
(2)  Not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury in any one (1) accident. 
(3)  Not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for damage to property, other than the towed vehicle and its contents while being towed and while in storage. 
(4)  Not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in garagekeeper's legal liability, which must include fire, explosion, theft, riot and civil commotion, vandalism, collision with a deductible no greater than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(c)  Each policy required hereunder shall contain an endorsement providing for thirty (30) days' notice to the Monroeville Police Department prior to any material change therein or cancellation thereof. 
(d)  A copy of the certificate of insurance is to be filed with the Monroeville Police Department. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88) 
Sec. 17.5-26. - Operation. 
    All operators shall comply with the following: 
(1)  No operator shall proceed to the scene of an accident without being requested to do so by the Monroeville Police Department. 
a.  No operator shall solicit business at the scene of an accident. 
b.  No operator shall speed or drive recklessly while answering a call, nor jam-up the scene of a wreck. 
(2)  Any owner or driver of a vehicle requesting the use of a specific wrecker must sign a written request, indicating that he has requested such wrecker. This form is furnished by the investigating officer and signed in his presence. 
(3)  Authorization permits shall be considered personal to the holder thereof and shall be issued only to some definite legal business operating wrecker service, and shall not be subject to lease, nor shall the holder thereof sublet or permit the exercise by another in any manner, of the rights or privileges granted thereunder. 
(4)  No wrecker service will use the amber light enroute to or when making a service or wrecker call. The use of the amber flashing or rotating light is authorized at the scene of an accident, and when towing the vehicle from the scene; or when the operator has been specifically authorized by the Monroeville Police Department dispatcher to do so in an emergency situation. 
(5)  Each wrecker business will furnish the chief of police with one (1) telephone number to be used for requests for services during the day and one (1) telephone number to be used for requests for services during the night. Any change in the aforementioned telephone numbers shall be immediately transmitted to the chief of police. 
(6)  Maintain twenty-four-hour service. 
(7)  Accept no request for services unless the operator has a vehicle immediately available to perform the requested service. 
(8)  No wrecker operator shall respond to a call when he has obviously been drinking. 
(9)  No owner or operator shall be on the rotation list who has been convicted of a felony involving grand larceny, theft of property, etc., or a misdemeanor or felony involving either force, violence, or moral turpitude. 
(10)  No owner or operator shall be on the rotation list who habitually frequents beer taverns, consorts with or allows loafing on the premises of known thieves, thugs, or convicted felons. 
(11)  No wrecker owner or operator shall be on the rotation list unless said driver or owner or operator is proficient and competent in the operation of said wrecker. 
(12)  No person shall operate or be allowed to operate any wrecker for hire unless such operator has a valid Alabama Driver's License. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88) 
Sec. 17.5-27. - Rotation log. 
    The following items shall govern the use of the rotation log in each area: 
(1)  When an operator receives a request for services from the Monroeville Police Department and no services are rendered the operator will not lose his position on the rotation log. 
(2)  If an operator has received a request for services, and he has not arrived within a reasonable length of time, the Monroeville Police Department reserves the right to request the services of the next operator on the rotation log. Under these circumstances, the operator who receives the first request for services will lose his position on the rotation log. Any wrecker company who is consistently tardy in reporting to wreck scenes when summoned shall be removed from the rotation log. 
(3)  When emergency conditions necessitate, the Monroeville Police Department reserves the right to request the services of the operator who is best able to handle the emergency and can reach the scene in the shortest time, regardless of the operator's position on the rotation log. If a call is made under these circumstances, the operator making such a call will be repositioned accordingly on the rotation log. 
(4)  Whenever heavy equipment or large vehicles are involved in an accident and it is determined that the wrecker next up on the rotation list does not have adequate equipment to handle the accident then the Monroeville Police Department reserves the right to call the wrecker business nearest the top of the list that is best able to handle the situation. If a call is made under these circumstances, the operator making such a call will be repositioned accordingly on the rotation list. 
(5)  Have valid business license issued by city clerk of the City of Monroeville, Alabama. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88) 
Sec. 17.5-28. - Applications. 
General: 
(1)  Each wrecker business desiring to be placed on the Monroeville Police Department rotation wrecker list shall file a written request to the chief of police. 
(2)  The chief of police will furnish each wrecker business making a request to be placed on the rotation list, a copy of the rules and regulations pertaining to the operation of wreckers on the Monroeville Police Department wrecker rotation list. 
(3)  The Monroeville Police Department will order an investigation of the requesting wrecker business and determine if the business meets all qualifications that are required to be placed on the Monroeville Police Department rotation list. 
(4)  The investigating officer will inspect all equipment that is to be used by the wrecker business and determine if it complies with all regulations. He will file his completed investigation with the chief of police. 
(5)  The wrecker business will furnish the Monroeville Police Department with a certificate of insurance form that indicates the policy numbers, policy period and the amount of coverage. This "form" will be provided by the Monroeville Police Department. 
(6)  When the chief of police is satisfied that the wrecker business is qualified, he will issue the wrecker company an "authorization permit" and place the company on the Monroeville Police Department rotation list. Subsequent to the date of the ordinance codified in this section (June 3, 2014), no wrecker business which has its primary place of business located outside the city limits of Monroeville, Alabama shall be qualified for an authorization permit. 
(7)  The total number of wrecker businesses on the rotation list shall be limited to seven (7) at any one (1) time. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88; Ord. of 6-3-14) 
Sec. 17.5-29. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  Violation of these regulations shall be cause for elimination of the operator from the rotation log of the Monroeville Police Department in which the operator is located. Said removal shall be for a period of time not less than ten (10) days nor more than one (1) year. An operator may also be removed from the rotation log for charging exorbitant fees for services. 
(1)  Upon receipt of notification of removal from the rotation log, the operator may within fifteen (15) days submit written request for a hearing to be held in Monroeville before the Monroeville Police Department. The receipt of a written request by the Monroeville Police Department for a hearing within the prescribed time shall stay the removal from the rotation log pending final disposition unless it is determined that it would endanger public safety to allow said operator to continue operating. 
(2)  The department shall reinstate to the rotation log the removed operator upon written application after the period of removal has elapsed and after the department has determined such operator is in compliance with all regulations pertaining to the Monroeville Police Department rotation wreckers. 
(b)  If any violations of these regulations is deemed to be of such an emergency nature as to endanger public safety, the department shall immediately suspend the authority for operating of the operator committing such violation. 
(c)  No applications for reinstatement to the rotation log or for reinstatement of operating privileges resulting from violation of these regulations will be considered as a result of a transfer of the suspended operator's business interest unless such transfer was by a bona fide sale of a majority of the assets of the business for a reasonable condition [consideration]. 
(Ord. of 2-2-88) 
Chapter 18 - WELLS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of March 22, 1977, specifically amended the Code by adding § 17-15. In order to facilitate classification and future expansion, said provisions have been redesignated Ch. 18, §§ 18-1-18-11 as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 17. 

Sec. 18-1. - Permit required to dig, enlarge, repair, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, drill, bore, construct, enlarge or repair any well for the withdrawal of water in the city or the police jurisdiction thereof, until a permit therefor has been obtained from the city council. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-2. - Application for permit; information to be shown. 
    Any person desiring to dig, drill, bore, construct, enlarge or repair any well for the withdrawal of water in the city, or the police jurisdiction thereof, shall before commencing such work make application for the permit required by section 18-1 to the city council. The application shall be made in writing, subscribed and sworn to by the person owning the premises on which the well is located or proposed to be located, or by an officer of the corporation owning the premises on which the well is located or proposed to be located, and also by the person having charge of the actual work of digging, drilling, boring, constructing, enlarging or repairing such well. It shall contain complete and accurate information with respect to the size, depth, location, approximate capacity, ownership and use of such well and any other pertinent information, including a statement of the purpose for which the supply from such well is to be used and where the surplus or overthrow water is to be discharged. It shall be unlawful for any person to make any false or misleading statement in any such application. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-3. - Permit to specify work authorized; failure to comply with terms of permit. 
    Each permit issued as required in section 18-1 shall specify clearly the work which is authorized to be done, and it shall be unlawful for any person to dig, drill, bore, construct, enlarge or repair any well in the city or the police jurisdiction thereof, for the withdrawal of water contrary to, or not authorized by, the terms of the permit issued for the work. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-4. - Bond required of persons engaged in business of well digging, repairing, etc. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person licensed to engage in the business of digging, drilling, boring, constructing, enlarging or repairing any well used, or to be used for the withdrawal or securing of water in the city, or the police jurisdiction thereof, before engaging in such business, to give as surety a bond, payable to the city, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), such bond to be executed by some suitable surety company duly authorized to do business in the city. 
(b)  Such bond shall be approved by the city clerk-treasurer and filed with him, and conditioned that any person engaged in the business of digging, drilling, boring, constructing, enlarging or repairing of wells will faithfully observe all the laws of the State of Alabama, and the ordinances of the city pertaining to such business. The city shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims arising from accidents and damages of any character whatsoever caused by the negligence of such person doing such work, or by unfavorable or inadequate work done by such person. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-5. - Form of bond. 
    The bond to be given in accordance with the provisions of section 18-4 shall be in the following form: 
"Bond 
Know All Men By These Presents: 
    "That we, ________________________________________, hereinafter called Principal and _________, as Surety, are held and firmly bound unto the City of Monroeville, a municipal corporation, in the sum of One Thousand Dollars, for the payment of which well and truly to be made we hereby bind ourselves, our heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns, jointly and severally, firmly by these presents: 
    "The condition of the foregoing obligation is such, however, that, 
    " Whereas, the said Principal is engaged in the business of digging, drilling, boring, constructing, enlarging and repairing of wells in the City of Monroeville and the police jurisdiction thereof. Now if said Principal shall faithfully observe all ordinances and laws of the said City pertaining to said business, whether now or hereafter enacted, together with all rules and regulations established under the authority of said laws or ordinances, and shall perform in a workmanlike manner all work undertaken by said Principal in the prosecution of said business or businesses and shall indemnify and save harmless the City of Monroeville from all liability occasioned or arising from acts done or omitted by said Principal, his or its servants and agents in doing said work, or from any unfaithful or inadequate work; and shall defend all suits brought against the City of Monroeville, based in whole or in part, upon any act or default for which the Principal is responsible, and shall pay the costs and expenses thereof and shall pay any damage that any person, firm or corporation may sustain by reason of violation of said laws, ordinances or regulations of the City of Monroeville by said Principal or its servants or agents in the prosecution of said business or businesses, then this bond to be void, otherwise to remain in full force and effect. 
    "Any person, firm or corporation injured in person or property by reason of any violation of said laws, ordinances or regulations of the City of Monroeville by said Principal, or by any act, default or omission constituting a breach of any of the conditions of this bond, may maintain a suit or action hereon for such injury. 
    "If the Surety shall so elect, this bond may be canceled by giving thirty (30) days' notice in writing to the Clerk-Treasurer of the City of Monroeville and this bond shall be deemed canceled at the expiration of said thirty (30) days; the Surety remaining liable, however, subject to all the terms, conditions and provisions of this Bond, for any act or acts covered by this Bond which may have been committed by the Principal up to the Date of such Cancellation. 
    " In Witness Whereof, said Principal and said Surety have executed this bond and affixed their seals at Monroeville, Alabama, on this the _____ day of _____, 19___. 
      _______ (Seal) 
      _______ (Seal) 
      _______ (Seal) 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-6. - Beneficiaries of bond. 
    The bond required by section 18-4 shall be for the benefit of all persons injured or aggrieved by any violation of or neglect to observe the provisions of any rule, regulation, law or ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-7. - Penalty for failure to secure bond. 
    Any person who engages in the digging, drilling, boring, constructing, enlarging or repairing of any well in the city, or police jurisdiction thereof, without first filing with the clerk-treasurer of the city the bond required in section 18-4 and securing the approval of such bond by the clerk-treasurer of the city, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-8. - Connection between wells and city system prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, tenant or one having charge over property upon which a well is located, to make or cause to be made, or permit to continue to exist, any physical connection between such well and its pumping system, and the water distribution system of the city. Valving (check, manual or automatic) placed between the private supply and the distribution system of the city shall not constitute satisfactory compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-9. - Required distinction between systems in industrial uses. 
    Industrial plants using wells for industrial water, and water from the city distribution system for human use and consumption, shall in addition to maintaining complete physical separation of the two (2) supplies, paint red all pipes carrying the industrial supply. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-10. - Wells not to be used as discharging point. 
    It is declared to be unlawful and dangerous to the public health for any well within the city, and the police jurisdiction thereof, to be employed as a discharge point for any waters or waste of any kind, liquid, inorganic or organic. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
Sec. 18-11. - Authority to remove well property from city distribution system upon violation. 
    In the event of a violation of any of the provisions of sections 18-8 through 18-11, the manager of the Monroeville Water Board is hereby empowered and directed to disconnect and remove in an appropriate manner the property served by the said well system from the city distribution system. 
(Ord. of 3-22-77) 
APPENDIX A - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Formerly, App. A contained the city's zoning ordinance, enacted in July of 1969. Subsequently such ordinance was amended in its entirety by an ordinance adopted Mar. 26, 1985, which, pursuant to the city's direction, is not set out at length herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 

APPENDIX B - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The subdivision ordinance, enacted July 8, 1968, is set out herein substantially as enacted. Amendments are cited in parentheses following amended sections or subsections. 
Cross reference- Planning commission, § 2-13. 

ARTICLE I. - PURPOSE 
    These regulations are enacted to provide for the proper arrangement of streets in relation to other existing or planned streets and to the master plan, for adequate and convenient open spaces for traffic, utilities, access of fire-fighting apparatus, recreation, light and air, and for the avoidance of congestion of population, including minimum width and area of lots, and the extent to which streets and other ways shall be graded and improved and to which water and sewer and other utility mains, piping, or other facilities shall be installed. 
ARTICLE II. - AUTHORITY AND JURISDICTION 

Sec. 1. - Authority. 
    Under the authority of Title 37, Chapter 16, Article 3, sections 797-803, inclusive, Code of Alabama, 1940 (Recompiled 1958), which sections are hereby made a part of these regulations, this ordinance is adopted, a copy of which has been certified to the probate judge of Monroe County. 
Sec. 2. - Jurisdiction. 
    From and after the date of adoption, these regulations shall govern all subdivisions of land within the corporate limits of the city, as now or hereafter established, and of all land located within the planning jurisdiction of the city. 
    Any owner of land within the limits of said subdivision jurisdiction wishing to subdivide land shall submit to the planning commission a plat of the subdivision which shall conform to the minimum requirements set forth in these regulations. No plat of a subdivision lying within such territory or part thereof shall be filed or recorded in the office of the probate judge, and no subdivider may proceed with improvement or sale of lots in a subdivision until such subdivision plat shall have been approved by the planning commission and such approval entered in writing on the plat by the secretary of the planning commission. 
ARTICLE III. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 3. - General. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, all words shall have the customary dictionary meaning. The present tense includes the future tense. The singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular. The word "person" includes a firm, corporation, association, organization, trust or partnership. The word "lot" includes "plot" or "parcel". The word "building" includes "structure". The word "shall" is mandatory. The word "may" is permissive. 
Sec. 4. - Specific definitions. 
    When used in this regulation, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning given in this section: 
(4.1)  Alley shall mean a minor public way having a narrow right-of-way and affording a secondary means of access to abutting properties. 
(4.2)  Arterial streets are those which are used primarily for moving fast or heavy traffic. Arterial streets are designated on the sketch thoroughfare plan. 
(4.3)  Block shall be a tract or parcel of land entirely surrounded by public highways or streets, other than alleys. 
(4.4)  Building setback line shall mean a line parallel to the property line in front of which no structure may be erected. 
(4.5)  Certificate of occupancy shall mean the instrument issued by the building inspector of the city when a building has been inspected and found to meet city codes and ordinances relating to construction. Such certificate authorizes occupancy of said building. 
(4.6)  City shall mean the City of Monroeville, Alabama, together with its planning jurisdiction. 
(4.7)  City clerk shall mean the duly designated clerk of the City of Monroeville, Alabama. 
(4.8)  City council shall mean the city council of the City of Monroeville, Alabama. 
(4.9)  City's engineer shall mean the duly designated engineer of the City of Monroeville, Alabama. 
(4.10)  City specifications shall mean all construction specifications which have been adopted by the city council or as required by the city planning commission and all utility departments. 
(4.11)  Collector street shall mean a street which carries traffic from minor streets to the system of major streets. 
(4.12)  Comprehensive plan shall mean any legally adopted part or element of the comprehensive plan of the City of Monroeville or its environs. This may include, but is not limited to: Zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, community facilities plan, sketch thoroughfare plan, capital expenditures plan, and land development plan. 
(4.13)  Corner lot shall be a lot abutting upon two (2) or more streets at their intersection. 
(4.14)  Cul-de-sac shall mean a short street designed to have one end permanently closed; the closed end terminated by a vehicular turn-around. 
(4.15)  Double front lot shall be a lot having frontage on two (2) non-intersecting streets as distinguished from a corner lot. 
(4.16)  Easement shall mean a grant of rights by the property owner for use by the city or its licensee of a strip of land for specified purposes. 
(4.17)  Final plat shall mean a plat of a tract of land which meets the requirements of these regulations and is in form for recording in the office of the probate judge of Monroe County, Alabama. 
(4.18)  Group development shall mean a development comprising two or more structures built on a single lot, tract or parcel of land and designed for occupancy by separate families, firms, or other enterprises. 
(4.19)  Half-street shall mean a street which does not meet the minimum right-of-way widths as set forth in these regulations. 
(4.20)  Health department shall mean the Monroe County Health Department, State of Alabama. 
(4.21)  Lot shall mean a parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership or for building development. 
(4.22)  Marginal access street shall be a street which is parallel and adjacent to an arterial street and which shall provide access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
(4.23)  Minor streets shall be all streets, both existing and proposed, which are used primarily for access to the abutting properties. 
(4.24)  Monument shall mean any permanent object serving to indicate a limit to or mark a boundary. 
(4.25)  Owner's engineer shall mean the engineer registered and in good standing with the state board of registration of Alabama, who is the agent, in his professional capacity, of the owner of land which is proposed to be subdivided or which is in the process of being subdivided. 
(4.26)  Planning commission shall mean the planning commission for the City of Monroeville, Alabama. 
(4.27)  Preliminary plat shall mean a tentative plan of a proposed subdivision submitted to the planning commission for its consideration. 
(4.28)  Probate judge shall mean the judge of probate of Monroe County, Alabama. 
(4.29)  Sidewalk shall mean a walkway constructed of concrete four (4) inches thick and a minimum of four (4) feet wide in residential areas. The most stringent requirements for sidewalks as set out in the Monroeville zoning ordinance and subdivision regulations shall apply. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROCEDURE 

Sec. 5. - Outline of procedure. 
(5.1)  Preliminary plat requirements: To prevent undue hardship on the subdivider through possible required plat revisions, a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision at a scale not smaller than one hundred (100) feet to the inch shall first be submitted to the planning commission in duplicate and shall give the following information: 
(a)  The subdivision name, the names and addresses of the owners and of the designer of the plat, who shall be a professional engineer, architect, or land surveyor registered to practice in the State of Alabama, or landscape architect acceptable to the planning commission. 
(b)  Date, approximate north point, and a graphic scale. 
(c)  The location of existing and platted property lines, streets, buildings, watercourses, railroads, sewers, bridges, culverts, drainpipes, water mains, and any public utility easements, both on the land subdivided and on the adjoining land; the names of the adjoining property owners and subdivisions. 
(d)  The names of streets, locations, widths, and other dimensions of proposed streets, alleys, easements and other open spaces, reservations, lot lines, and building lines. 
(e)  Contours at vertical intervals of not more than five (5) feet when required by the planning commission. 
(f)  Profiles of all streets showing natural and finished grades drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals one hundred (100) feet horizontal and one inch equals ten (10) feet vertical when required by the planning commission and such plans as may be specifically required under subsection (21.5). 
(g)  Preliminary sketch plans of proposed utility layouts, (sewer, water, and electricity) showing feasible connections, where possible, to existing and proposed utility systems. 
(h)  If the proposed subdivision does not lie within the force and effect of an existing zoning ordinance, the preliminary plat shall be accompanied by a plan indicating the proposed use of the lots and by the instrument to be used in establishing restrictions. 
(5.2)  Review of preliminary plat: The planning commission review of this preliminary plat shall be governed by the procedure set forth in Title 37, Article 3, Section 779, of the 1940 Code of Alabama.
